translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE men from fire-sticks, with their hands' swift movement, have, in deep thought, engendered glorious Agni, Far-seen, with pointed flame, Lord of the homestead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Vasus set that Agni in the dwelling, fair to behold, for help from every quarter: Who, in the home for ever, must be honoured.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine thou before us, Agni, well-enkindled, with flame, Most Youthful God, that never fadeth. To thee come all our sacrificial viands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Among all fires these fires have shone most brightly, splendid with light, begirt by noble heroes, Where men of lofty birth sit down together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Victorious Agni, grant us wealth with wisdom, wealth with brave sons, famous and independent, Which not a foe who deals in magic conquers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To whom, the Strong, at morn and eve comes, maid-like, the ladle dropping oil, with its oblation. Wealth-seeking comes to him his own devotion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Burn up all malice with those flames, O Agni, wherewith of old thou burntest up Jarutha, And drive away in silence pain and sickness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With him who lighteth up thy splendour, Agni, excellent, pure, refulgent, Purifier, Be present, and with us through these our praises.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the patriarchal men, the mortals who have in many places spread thy lustre,— Be gracious to us here for their sake also.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let these men, heroes in the fight with foemen, prevail against all godless arts of 4magic,— These who ipprove the noble song I sing thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us not sit in want of men, O Agni, without descendants, heroleu, about thee: But, O House-Friend, in houses full of children.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By sacrifice which the Steeds' Lord ever visits, there make our dwelling rich in seed and offspring, Increasing still with lineal successors.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guard us, O Agni, from the hated demon, guard us from malice of the churlish sinner: Allied with thee may I subdue assailants.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this same fire of mine surpass all others, this fire where offspring, vigorous and firm-handed, Wins, on a thousand paths, what ne’er shall perish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is that Agni, saviour from the foeman, who guards the kindler of the flame from sorrow: Heroes of noble lineage serve and tend him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is that Agni, served in many places, whom the rich lord who brings oblation kindles, And round him goes the priest at sacrifices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, may we with riches in possession bring thee continual ofierings in abundance, Using both means to draw thee to our worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, bear thou, Eternal, these most welcome oblations to the Deities' assembly: Let them enjoy our very fragrant presents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us not up, Agni, to want of heroes, to wretched clothes, to need, to destitution. Yield us not, Holy One, to fiend or hunger; injure us not at home or in the forest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give strength and power to these my prayers, O Agni; O God, pour blessings on our chiefs and nobles. Grant that both we and they may share thy bounty. Ye Gods, protect us evermore with blessings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou Agni, swift to hear, art fair of aspect: beam forth, O Son of Strength, in full effulgence. Let me not want, with thee, a son for ever: let not a manly hero ever fail us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Condemn us not to indigence, O Agni, beside these flaming fires which Gods have kindled; Nor, even after fault, let thy displeasure, thine as a God, O Son of Strength, o’ertake us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, fair of face, the wealthy mortal who to the Immortal offers his oblation. Hath him who wins him treasure by his Godhead, to whom the prince, in need, goes supplicating.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Knowing our chief felicity, O Agni, bring hither ample riches to our nobles, Wherewith we may enjoy ourselves, O Victor, with undiminished life and hero children.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give strength and power to these my prayers, O Agni; O God, pour blessings on bur chiefs and nobles. Grant that both we and they may share thy bounty. Ye Gods, protect us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN II. Āprīs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GLADLY accept, this day, our fuel, Agni: send up thy sacred smoke and shine sublimely. Touch the celestial summits with thy columns, and overspread thee with the rays of Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With sacrifice to these we men will honour the majesty of holy Narāśaṁsa- To these the pure, most wise, the thought. inspirers, Gods who enjoy both sorts of our oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will extol at sacrifice for ever, as men may do, Agni whom Manu kindled, Your very skilful Asura, meet for worship, envoy between both worlds, the truthful speaker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bearing the sacred grass, the men who serve him strew it with reverence, on their knees, by Agni. Calling him to the spotted grass, oil-sprinkled, adorn him, ye Adhvaryus, with oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With holy thoughts the pious have thrown open Doors fain for chariots in the Gods’ assembly. Like two full mother cows who lick their youngling, like maidens for the gathering, they adorn them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And let the two exalted Heavenly Ladies, Morning and Night, like a cow good at milking, Come, much-invoked, and on our grass be seated ' wealthy, deserving worship, for our welfare.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: You, Bards and Singers at men's sacrifices, both filled with wisdom, I incline to worship. Send up our offerings when we call upon you, and so among the Gods obtain us treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Bhāratī with all her Sisters, Iḷā accordant with the Gods, with mortals Agni, Sarasvatī with all her kindred Rivers, come to this grass, Three Goddesses, and seat them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well pleased with us do thou, O God, O Tvaṣṭar, give ready issue to our procreant vigour, Whence springs the hero, powerful, skilled in action, lover of Gods, adjuster of the press-stones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send to the Gods the oblation, Lord of Forests, and let the Immolator, Agni, dress it. He as the truer Priest shall offer worship, for the God'sgenerations well he knoweth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come thou to us, O Agni, duly kindled, together with the potent Gods and Indra. On this our grass sit Aditi, happy Mother, and let our Hail! delight the Gods Immortal. Next: HYMN III. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ASSOCIATE with fires, make your God Agni envoy at sacrifice, best skilled in worship, Established firm among mankind, the Holy, flame-crowned and fed with oil, the Purifier.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a steed neighing eager for the pasture, when he hath stepped forth from the great enclosure: Then the wind following blows upon his splendour, and, straight, the path is black which thou hast travelled.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From thee a Bull but newly born, O Agni, the kindled everlasting flames rise upward. Aloft to heaven thy ruddy smoke ascendeth: Agni, thou speedest to the Gods as envoy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou whose fresh lustre o’er the earth advanceth when greedily with thy jaws thy food thou eatest. Like a host hurried onward comes thy lasso: fierce, with thy tongue thou piercest, as ’twere barley.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men have decked him both at eve and morning, Most Youthful Agni, as they tend a courser. They kindle him, a guest within his dwelling: bright shines the splendour of the worshipped Hero.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O fair of face, beautiful is thine aspect when, very near at hand, like gold thou gleamest, Like Heaven's thundering roar thy might approaches, and like the wondrous Sun thy light thou showest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That we may worship, with your Hail to Agni! with sacrificial cakes and fat oblations, Guard us, O Agni, with those boundless glories as with a hundred fortresses of iron.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine are resistless songs for him who offers, and hero-giving hymns wherewith thou savest; With these, O Son of Strength, O Jātavedas, guard us, preserve these princes and the singers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When forth he cometh, like an axe new-sharpened, pure in his form, resplendent in his body, Sprung, sought with eager longing, from his Parents, for the Gods’ worship, Sage and Purifier:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine this felicity on us, O Agni: may we attain to perfect understanding. All happiness be theirs who sing and praise thee. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN IV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BRING forth your gifts to his refulgent splendour, your hymn as purest offering to Agni, To him who goes as messenger with knowledge between all songs of men and Gods in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise must this Agni be, though young and tender, since he was born, Most Youthful, of his Mother; He who with bright teeth seizeth fast the forests, and eats his food, though plenteous, in a moment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before his presence must we all assemble, this God's whom men have seized in his white splendour. This Agni who hath brooked that men should seize him hath shone for man with glow insufferable.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far-seeing hath this Agni been established, deathless mid mortals, wise among the foolish. Here, O victorious God, forbear to harm us: may weforever share thy gracious favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath occupied his God-made dwelling, Agni, in wisdom hath surpassed Immortals. A Babe unborn, the plants and trees support him, and the earth beareth him the All-sustainer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is Lord of Amṛta. in abundance, Lord of the gift of wealth and hero valour, Victorious God, let us not sit about thee like men devoid of strength, beauty, and worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The foeman's treasure may be won with labour: may we be masters of our own possessions. Agni, no son is he who springs from others: lengthen not out the pathways of the foolish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unwelcome for adoption is the stranger, one to be thought of as another's offipring, Though grown familiar by continual presence. May our strong hero come, freshly triumphant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guard us from him who would assail us, Agni; preserve us O thou Victor, from dishonour. Here let the place of darkening come upon thee: may wealth be ours, desirable, in thousands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine this felicity on us, O Agni: may we attain to perfect understanding. All happiness be theirs who sing and praise thee. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN V. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BRING forth your song of praise to mighty Agni, the speedy messenger of earth and heaven, Vaiśvānara, who, with those who wake, hath waxen great in the lap of all the Gods Immortal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sought in the heavens, on earth is Agni stablished, leader of rivers, Bull of standing waters. Vaiśvānara when he hath grown in glory, shines on the tribes of men with light and treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For fear of thee forth fled the dark-hued races, scattered abroad, deserting their possessions, When, glowing, O Vaiśvānara, for Pūru, thou Agni didst light up and rend their castles.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni Vaiśvānara, both Earth and Heaven submit them to thy threefold jurisdiction. Refulgent in thine undecaying lustre thou hast invested both the worlds with splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the tawny horses, loudly neighing our resonant hymns that drop with oil, attend thee; Lord of the tribes, our Charioteer of riches, Ensign of days, Vaiśvānara of mornings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee, O bright as Mitra, Vasus seated the might of Aduras, for they loved thy spirit. Thou dravest Dasyus from their home, O Agni, and broughtest forth broad light to light the Ārya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born in the loftiest heaven thou in a moment reachest, like wind, the place where Gods inhabit. Thou, favouring thine offspring, roaredst loudly when giving life to creatures, Jātavedas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send us that strength, Vaiśvānara, send it, Agni, that strength, O Jātavedas, full of splendour, Wherewith, all-bounteous God, thou pourest riches, as fame wide-spreading, on the man who offers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, bestow upon our chiefs and nobles that famous power, that wealth which feedeth many. Accordant with the Vasus and the Rudras, Agni, Vaiśvānara, give us sure protection. Next: HYMN VI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRAISE of the Asura, high imperial Ruler, the Manly One in whom the folk shall triumph- I laud his deeds who is as strong as Indra, and lauding celebrate the Fort-destroyer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sage, Sing, Food, Light,—they bring him from the mountain, the blessed Sovran of the earth and heaven. I decorate with songs the mighty actions which Agni, Fort-destroyer, did aforetime.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The foolish, faithless, rudely-speaking niggards, without belief or sacrifice or worship,— Far far sway hath Agni chased those Dasytis, and, in the cast, hath turned the godless westward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who brought eastward, manliest with his prowess, the Maids rejoicing in the western darkness, That Agni I extol, the Lord of riches, unyielding tamer of assailing foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who brake down the walls with deadly weapons, and gave the Mornings to anoble Husband, Young Agni, who with conquering strength subduing the tribes of Nahus made them bring their tribute.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In whose protection all men rest by nature, desiring to enjoy his gracious favour- Agni Vaiśvānara in his Parents, bosom hath found the choicest seat in earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vaiśvānara the God, at the sun's setting, hath taken to himself deep-hidden treasures: Agni hath taken them from earth and heaven, from the sea under and the sea above us. Next: HYMN VII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I SEND forth even your God, victorious Agni, like a strong courser, with mine adoration. Herald of sacrifice be he who knoweth he hath reached Gods, himself, with measured motion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By paths that are thine own come hither, Agni, joyous, delighting in the Gods’ alliance, Making the heights of earth roar with thy fury, burning with eager teeth the woods and forests.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The grass is strewn; the sacrifice advances adored as Priest, Agni is made propitious, Invoking both All-boon-bestowing Mothers of whom, Most Youthful! thou wast born to help us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forthwith the men, the best of these for wisdom, have made him leader in the solemn worship. As Lord in homes of men is Agni stablished, the Holy One, the joyous, sweetly speaking.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath come, chosen bearer, and is seated in man's home, Brahman, Agni, the Supporter, He whom both Heaven anct Earth exalt and strengthenwhom, Giver of all boons, the Hotar worships.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These have passed all in glory, who, the manly, have wrought with skill the hymn of adoration; Who, listening, have advanced the people's welfare, and set their thoughts on this my holy statute.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We, the Vasisthas, now implore thee, Agni, O Son of Strength, the Lord of wealth and treasure. Thou hast brought food to singers and to nobles. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN VIII. Agni

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE King whose face is decked with oil is kindled with homage offered by his faithful servant. The men, the priests adore him with oblations. Agni hath shone forth when the dawn is breaking.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, he hath been acknowledged as most mighty, the joyous Priest of men, the youthful Agni. He, spreading o’er the earth, made light around him, and grew among the plants with blackened fellies..

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How dost thou decorate our hymn, O Agni? What power dost thou exert when thou art lauded? When, Bounteous God, may we be lords of riches, winners of precious wealth which none may conquer?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far famed is this the Bhārata's own Agni he shineth like the Sun with lofty splendour. He who hath vanquished Pūru in the battle, the heavenly guest hath glowed in full refulgence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Full many oblations are in thee collected: with all thine aspects thou hast waxen gracious. Thou art already famed as praised and lauded, yet still, O nobly born, increase thy body.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be this my song, that winneth countless treasure, engendered with redoubled force for Agni, That, splendid, chasing sickness, slaying demons, it may delight our friend and bless the singers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We, the Vasisthas, now implore thee, Agni, O Son of Strength, the Lord of wealth and riches. Thou hast brought food to singers and to nobles. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN IX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ROUSED from their bosom is the Dawns' beloved, the joyous Priest, most sapient, Purifier. He gives a signal both to Gods and mortals, to Gods oblations, riches to the pious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most wise is he who, forcing doors of Paṇis, brought the bright Sun to us who feedeth many. The cheerful Priest, men's Friend and home-companion, through still night's darkness he is made apparent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise, ne.'er deceived, uncircumscribed, refulgent, our gracious guest, a Friend with good attendants, Shines forth with wondrous light before the Mornings; the young plants hath he entered, Child of Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seeking our gatherings, he, your Jātavedas, hath shone adorable through human ages, Who gleams refulgent with his lovely lustre: the kine have waked to meet him when enkindled.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Go on thy message to the Gods, and fail not, O Agni, with their band who pray and worship. Bring all the Gods that they may give us riches, Sarasvatī, the Maruts, Aśvins, Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vasiṣṭha, when enkindling thee, O Agni, hath slain jarutha. Give us wealth in plenty. Sing praise in choral song, O Jātavedas. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN X. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE hath sent forth, bright, radiant, and refulgent, like the Dawn's Lover, his far-spreading lustre. Pure in his splendour shines the golden Hero: our longing thoughts hath he aroused and wakened.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, like the Sun, hath shone while Morn is breaking, and priests who weave the sacrifice sing praises, Agni, the God, who knows their generations and visits Gods, most bounteous, rapid envoy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our songs and holy hymns go forth to Agni, seeking the God and asking him for riches, Him fair to see, of goodly aspect, mighty, men's messenger who carries their oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: joined with the Vasus, Agni, bring thou Indra bring hither mighty Rudra with the Rudras, Aditi good to all men with Ādityas, Bṛhaspati All-bounteous, with the Singers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men eagerly implore at sacrifices Agni, Most Youthful God, the joyous Herald. For he is Lord and Ruler over riches, and for Gods’ worship an unwearied envoy. Next: HYMN XI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GREAT art thou, Agni, sacrifice's Herald: not without thee are deathless Gods made joyful. Come hither with all Deities about thee here take thy seat, the first, as Priest, O Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men with oblations evermore entreat thee, the swift, to undertake an envoy's duty. He on whose sacred grass with Gods thou sittest, to him, O Agni, are the days propitious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three times a day in thee are shown the treasures sent for the mortal who presents oblation. Bring the Gods hither like a man, O Agni: be thou our envoy, guarding us from curses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the lofty sacrifice is Agni, Agni is Lord of every gift presented. The Vasus were contented with his wisdom, so the Gods made him their oblationbearer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, bring the Gods to taste our presents: with Indra leading, here let them be joyful. Convey this sacrifice to Gods in heaven. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE with great reverence have approached The Youngest who hath shone forth well-kindled in his dwelling, With wondrous light between wide earth and heaven, well-worshipped, looking forth in all directions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through his great might o’ercoming all misfortunes, praised in the house is Agni Jātavedas. May he protect us from disgrace and trouble, both us who laud him and our noble patrons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, thou art Varuṇa and Mitra: Vasisthas with their holy hymns exalt thee. With thee be most abundant gain of treasure. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BRING song and hymn to Agni, Asura-slayer, enlightener of all and thought-bestower. Like an oblation on the grass, to please him, I bring this to Vaiśvānara, hymn-inspirer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou with thy flame, O Agni, brightly glowing, hast at thy birth filled full the earth and heaven. TIOU with thy might, Vaiśvānara Jātavedas, settest the Gods free frodi the curse that bound them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, when, born thou lookedst on all creatures, like a brisk herdsman moving round his cattle. The path to prayer, Vaiśvānara, thou foundest. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XIV Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH reverence and with offered gifts serve we the God whose flame is bright: Let us bring Jātavedas fuel, and adore Agni when we invoke the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, may we perform thy rites with fuel, and honour thee, O Holy one, with praises: Honour thee, Priest of sacrifice! with butter, thee, God of blessed light! with our oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Agni, with the Gods to our invoking, come, pleased, to offerings sanctified with Vaṣaṭ. May we be his who pays thee, God, due honour. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: OFFER oblations in his mouth, the bounteous God's whom we must serve. His who is nearest kin to us:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who for the Fivefold People's take hath seated him in every home Wise, Youthful, Master of the house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On all sides may that Agni guard our household folk and property; May he deliver us from woe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I have begotten this new hymn for Agni, Falcon of the sky: Will he not give us of his wealth?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose lories when he glows in front of sacrite are fair to see, Like wealth of one with hero sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he enjoy this hallowed gift, Agni accept our songs, who bears Oblations, best of worshippers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the house, whom men must seek, we set thee down, O Worshipped Onel Bright, rich in heroes, Agni! God

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine forth at night and morn: through thee with fires are we provided well. Thou, rich in heroes, art our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men come near thee for their gain, the singers with their songs of praise: Speech, thousandfold, comes near to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright, Purifier, meet for praise, Immortal with refulgent glow, Agni drives Rākṣasas away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, bring us abundant wealth, young Child of Strength, for this thou canst May Bhaga give us what is choice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, givest hero fame: Bhaga and Savitar the God, And Did give us what is good.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, preserve us from distress: consume our enemies, O God, Eternal, with the hottest flames.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, irresistible, be thou a mighty iron fort to us, With hundred walls for man's defence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou preserve us, eve and morn, from sorrow, from the wicked men, Infallible! by day and night. Next: HYMN XVI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH this my reverent hymn I call Agni for you, the Son of Strength, Dear, wisest envoy, served with noble sacrifice, immortal messenger of all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His two red horses, all-supporting, let him yoke: let him, well-worshipped, urge them fast. Then hath the sacrifice good prayers and happy end, and heavenly gift of wealth to men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The flame of him the Bountiful, the Much-invoked, hath mounted up, And his red-coloured smoke-clouds reach and touch the sky: the men are kindling Agni well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, thee Most Glorious One we make our messenger. Bring the Gods hither to the feast. Give us, O Son of Strength, all food that fcedeth man: give that for which we pray to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, art the homestead's Lord, our Herald at the sacrifice. Lord of all boons, thou art the Cleanser and a Sage. Pay worship, and enjoy the good.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give riches to the sacrificer, O Most Wise, for thou art he who granteth wealth. Inspire with zeal each priest at this our solemn rite; all who are skilled in singing praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni who art worshipped well, dear let our princes he to thee, Our wealthy patrons who are governors of men, who part, as gifts, their stalls of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They in whose home, her hand bearing the sacred oil, Iḷā sits down well-satisfied- Guard them, Victorious God, from slander and from harm. give us a refuge famed afar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, a Priest with pleasant tongue, most wise, and very near to us, Agni, bring riches hither to our liberal chiefs, and speed the oflering of our gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who bestow as bounty plenteous wealth of steeds, moved by desire of great renown- Do thou with saving help preserve them from distress, Most Youthful! with a hundred forts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God who gives your wealth demands a full libation poured to him. Pour ye it forth, then fill the vessel full again: then doth the God pay heed to you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him have the Gods appointed Priest of sacrifice, oblation-bearer, passing wise. Agni gives wealth and valour to the worshipper, to folk who offer up their gifts. Next: HYMN XVII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI, be kindled well with proper fuel, and let the grass be scattered wide about thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the impatient Portals be thrown open bring thou the Gods impatient to come hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Taste, Agni: serve the Gods with our oblation. Offer good sacrifices, Jātavedas!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Jātavedas pay fair sacrifices, worship andgratify the Gods Immortal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise God, win for us things that are all-goodly, and let the prayers, we pray today be fruitful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, even thee, the Son of Strength, O Agni, those Gods have made the bearer of oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee the God may we perform our worship: do thou, besought, grant us abundant riches. Next: HYMN XVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ALL is with thee, O Indra, all the treasures which erst our fathers won who sang thy praises. With thee are milch-kine good to milk, and horses: best winner thou of riches for the pious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For like a King among his wives thou dwellest: with glories, as a Sage, surround and help us. Make us, thy servants, strong for wealth, and honour our songs wirth kine and steeds and decoration.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here these our holy hymns with joy and gladness in pious emulation have approached thee. Hitherward come thy path that leads to riches: may we find shelter in thy favour, Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vasiṣṭha hath poured forth his prayers, desiring to milk thee like a cow in goodly pasture. All these my people call thee Lord of cattle: may Indra. come unto the prayer we offer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What though the floods spread widely, Indra made them shallow and easy for Sudās to traverse. He, worthy of our praises, caused the Simyu, foe of our hymn, to curse the rivers' fury.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eager for spoil was Turvaśa Purodas, fain to win wealth, like fishes urged by hunger. The Bhṛgus and the Druhyus quickly listened: friend rescued friend mid the two distant peoples.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Together came the Pakthas, the Bhalanas, the Alinas, the Sivas, the Visanins. Yet to the Trtsus came the Ārya's Comrade, through love of spoil and heroes' war, to lead them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fools, in their folly fain to waste her waters, they parted inexhaustible Paruṣṇī. Lord of the Earth, he with his might repressed them: still lay the herd and the affrighted herdsman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As to their goal they sped to their destruetion: they sought Paruṣṇī; e’en the swift returned not. Indra abandoned, to Sudās the manly, the swiftly flying foes, unmanly babblers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They went like kine unherded from the pasture, each clinging to a friend as chance directed. They who drive spotted steeds, sent down by Pṛśni, gave ear, the Warriors and the harnessed horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The King who scattered one-and-twenty people of both Vaikarna tribes through lust of glory- As the skilled priest clips grass within the chamber, so hath the Hero Indra, wrought their downfall.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, thunder-armed, o’erwhelmedst in the waters famed ancient Kavasa and then the Druhyu. Others here claiming friendship to their friendship, devoted unto thee, in thee were joyful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra at once with conquering might demolished all their strong places and their seven castles. The goods of Anu's son he gave to Trtsu. May we in sacrifice conquer scorned Pūru.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Anavas and Druhyus, seeking booty, have slept, the sixty hundred, yea, six thousand, And six-and-sixty heroes. For the pious were all these mighty exploits done by Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Trtsus under Indra's careful guidance came speeding like loosed waters rushing downward. The foemen, measuring exceeding closely, abandoned to Sudās all their provisions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The hero's side who drank the dressed oblation, Indra's denier, far o’er earth he scattered. Indra brought down the fierce destroyer's fury. He gave them various roads, the path's Controller.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: E’en with the weak he wrought this matchless exploit: e’en with a goat he did to death a lion. He pared the pillar's angles with a needle. Thus to Sudās Indra gave all provisions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee have all thine enemies submitted: e’en the fierce Bheda hast thou made thy subject. Cast down thy sharpened thunderbolt, O Indra, on him who harms the men who sing thy praises.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yamuna and the Trtsus aided Indra. There he stripped Bheda bare of all his treasures. The Ajas and the Sigrus and the Yaksus brought in to him as tribute heads of horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not to be scorned, but like Dawns past and recent, O Indra, are thy favours and thy riches. Devaka, Mānyamana's son, thou slewest, and smotest Śambara from the lofty mountain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who, from home, have gladdened thee, thy servants Parasara, Vasiṣṭha, Satayatu, Will not forget thy friendship, liberal Giver. So shall the days dawn prosperous for the princes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Priest-like, with praise, I move around the altar, earning Paijavana's reward, O Agni, Two hundred cows from Devavan's descendant, two chariots from Sudās with mares to draw them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gift of Paijavana, four horses bear me in foremost place, trained steeds with pearl to deck them. Sudās's brown steeds, firmly-stepping, carry me and my son for progeny and glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him whose fame spreads between wide earth and heaven, who, as dispenser, gives each chief his portion, Seven flowing Rivers glorify like Indra. He slew Yudhyamadhi in close encounter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Attend on him O ye heroic Maruts as on Sudās's father Divodāsa. Further Paijavana's desire with favour. Guard faithfully his lasting firm dominion. Next: HYMN XIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE like a bull with sharpened horns, terrific, singly excites and agitates all the people: Thou givest him who largely pours libations his goods who pours not, for his own possession.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, verily, Indra, gavest help to Kutsa, willingly giving car to him in battle, When, aiding Ārjuneya, thou subduedst to him both Kuyava and the Dāsa Śuṣṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Bold One, thou with all thine aids hast boldly holpen Sudās whose offerings were accepted, Pūru in winning land and slaying foemen, and Trasadasyu son of Purukutsa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At the Gods’ banquet, hero-souled! with Heroes, Lord of Bay Steeds, thou slewest many foemen. Thou sentest in swift death to sleep the Dasyu, both Cumuri and Dhuni, for Dabhīti.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These were thy mighty powers that, Thunder-wielder, thou swiftly crushedst nine-and-ninety castles: Thou capturedst the hundredth in thine onslaught; thou slewest Namuci, thou slewest Vṛtra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Old are the blessings, Indra, which thou gavest Sudās the worshipper who brought oblations. For thee, the Strong, I yoke thy strong Bay Horses: may our prayers reach thee and win strength, Most Mighty!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us not up, Lord of Bay Horses, Victor, in this thine own assembly, to the wicked. Deliver us with true and faithful succours: dear may we be to thee among the princes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we men, Maghavan, the friends thou lovest, near thee be joyful under thy protection. Fain to fulfil the wish of Atithigva humble. the pride of Turvaśa and Yadva.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Swiftly, in truth, O Maghavan, about thee men skilled in hymning sing their songs and praises. ' Elect us also into their assembly who by their calls on thee despoiled the niggards.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine are these lauds, O manliest of heroes, lauds which revert to us and give us riches. Favour these, Indra, when they fight with faemen, as Friend and Hero and the heroes' Helper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, lauded for thine aid, Heroic Indra, sped by our prayer, wax mighty in thy body. Apportion to us strength and habitations. Ye Gods, protect us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: STRONG, Godly-natured, born for hero exploit, man's Friend, hedoth whatever deed he willeth. Saving us e’en from great transgression, Indra, the Youthful, visiteth man's home with favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Waxing greatness Indra slayeth Vṛtra: the Hero with his aid hath helped the singer. He gave Sudās wide room and space, and often hath granted wealth to him who brought oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soldier unchecked, war-rousing, battling Hero, unconquered from of old, victorious ever, Indra the very strong hath scattered armies; yea, he hath slain each foe who fought against him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou with thy greatness hast filled full, O Indra, even both the worlds with might, O thou Most Mighty. Lord of Bays, Indra, brandishing his thunder, is gratified with Soma at the banquet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A Bull begat the Bull for joy of battle, and a strong Mother brought forth him the manly. He who is Chief of men, their armies' Leader, is strong Hero, bold, and fain for booty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The people falter not, nor suffer sorrow, who win themselves this God's terrific spirit. He who with sacrifices worships Indra is lord of wealth, law-born and law's protector.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whene’er the elder fain would help the younger the greater cometh to the lesser's present. Shall the Immortal sit aloof' inactive? O Wondrous Indra, bring us wondrous riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy dear folk, Indra, who present oblations, are, in chief place, thy friends, O Thunder-wielder. May we be best content in this thy favour, sheltered by One who slays not, but preserves us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee the mighty hymn hath clamoured loudly, and, Maghavan, the eloquent hath besought thee. Desire of wealth hath come upon thy singer: help us then, gakra, to our share of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Place us by food which thou hast given, O Indra, us and the wealthy patrons who command us. Let thy great power bring good to him who lauds thee. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRESSED is the juice divine with milk commingled: thereto hath Indra ever been accustomed. We wake thee, Lord of Bays, with sacrifices: mark this our laud in the wild joy of Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On to the rite they move, the grass they scatter, these Soma-drinkers eloquent in synod. Hither, for men to grasp, are brought the press-stones, far-thundering, famous, strong, that wait on heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thou settest free the many waters that were encompassed, Hero, by the Dragon. Down rolled, as if on chariots borne, the rivers: through fear of thee all things created tremble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Skilled in all manly deeds the God terrific hath with his weapons mastered these opponents. Indra in rapturous joy shook down their castles he slew them in his might, the Thunder-wielder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No evil spirits have impelled us, Indra, nor fiends, O Mightiest God, with their devices. Let our true God subdue the hostile rabble: let not the lewd approach our holy worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou in thy strength surpassest Earth and Heaven: the regions comprehend not all thy greatness. With thine own power and might thou slewest Vṛtra: no foe hath found the end of thee in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even the earlier Deities submitted their powers to thy supreme divine dominion. Indra wins wealth and deals it out to other's: men in the strife for booty call on Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The humble hath invoked thee for protection, thee, Lord of great felicity, O Indra. Thou with a hundred aids hast been our Helper: one who brings gifts like thee hath his defender.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we, O Indra, be thy friends for ever, eagerly, Conqueror, yielding greater homage. May, through thy grace, the strength of us who battle quell in the shock the onset of the foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Place us by food which thou hast given, O Indra, us and the wealthy patrons who command us. Let thy great power bring good to him who lauds thee. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XXII Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DRINK Soma, Lord of Bays, and let it cheer thee: Indra, the stone, like a well guided courser, Directed by the presser's arms hath pressed it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So let the draught of joy, thy dear companion, by which, O Lord of Bays, thou slayest foemen, Delight thee, Indra, Lord of princely treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mark closely, Maghavan, the words I utter, this eulogy recited by Vasiṣṭha: Accept the prayers I offer at thy banquet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear thou the call of the juice-drinking press-stone: hear thou the Brahman's hymn who sings and lauds thee. Take to thine inmost self these adorations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I know and ne’er forget the hymns and praises of thee, the Conqueror, and thy strength immortal. Thy name I ever utter. Self-Refulgent

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Among mankind many are thy libations, and many a time the pious sageinvokes thee. O Maghavan, be not long distant from us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All these libations are for thee, O Hero: to thee I offer these my prayers. that strengthen. Ever, in every place, must men invoke thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never do men attain, O Wonder-Worker, thy greatness, Mighty One, who must be lauded, Nor, Indra, thine heroic power and bounty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Among all Ṛṣis, Indra, old and recent, who have engendered hymns as sacred singers, Even with us be thine auspicious friendships. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRAYERS have been offered up through love of glory: Vasiṣṭha, honour Indra in the battle. He who with might extends through all existence hears words which I, his faithful servant, utter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A cry was raised which reached the Gods, O Indra, a cry to them to send us strength in combat. None among men knows his own life's duration: bear us in safety over these our troubles.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bays, the booty-seeking car I harness: my prayers have reached him who accepts them gladly. Indra, when he had slain resistless foemen, forced with his might the two world-halves asunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like barren cows, moreover, swelled the waters: the singen sought thy holy rite, O Indra. Come unto us as with his team comes Vāyu: thou, through our solemn hymns bestowest booty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may these gladdening draughts rejoice thee, Indra, the Mighty, very bounteous to the singer. Alone among the Gods thou pitiest mortals: O Hero, make thee glad at this libation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus the Vasisthas glorify with praises Indra, the Powerful whose arm wields thunder. Praised, may he guard our wealth in kine and heroes. Ye Gods, preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A HOME is made for thee to dwell in, Indra: O Much-invoked, go thitherwith the heroes. That thou, to prosper us, mayst be our Helper, vouchsafe us wealth, rejoice with draughts of Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thy wish, twice-strong, is comprehended: pressed is the Soma, poured are pleasant juices. This hymn of praise, from loosened tongue, made perfect, draws Indra to itself with loud invoking.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, thou Impetuous; God, from earth or heaven; come to our holy grass to drink the Soma. Hither to me let thy Bay Horses bring thee to listen to our hymns and make thee joyful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come unto us with all thine aids, accordant, Lord of Bay Steeds, accepting our devotions, Fair-helmeted, o’ercoming with the mighty, and lending us the strength of bulls, O Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As to the chariot pole a vigorous courser, this laud is brought to the great strong Upholder. This hymn solicits wealth of thee: in heaven, as ’twere above the sky, set thou our glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With precious things. O Indra, thus content us: may we attain to thine exalted favour. Send our chiefs plenteous food with hero children. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, where the ground is hard to traverse, smite down our foes, the mortals who assail us, Keep far from us the curse of the reviler: bring us accumulated store of treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: God of the fair helm, give Sudās a hundred succours, a thousand blessings, and thy bounty. Strike down the weapon of our mortal foeman: bestow upon us splendid fame and riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I wait the power of one like thee, O Indra, gifts of a Helper such as thou art, Hero. Strong, Mighty God, dwell with me now and ever: Lord of Bay Horses, do not thou desert us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here are the Kutsas supplicating Indra for might, the Lord of Bays for God-sent conquest. Make our foes ever easy to be vanquished: may we, victorious, win the spoil, O Hero.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With precious things, O Indra, thus content us: may we attain to thine exalted favour. Send our chiefs plenteous food with hero children. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SOMA unpressed ne’er gladdened liberal Indra, no juices pressed without a prayer have pleased him. I generate a laud that shall delight him, new and heroic, so that he may hear us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At every laud the Soma gladdens Indra: pressed juices please him as each psalm is chanted, What time the priests with one united effort call him to aid, as sons invoke their father.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These deeds he did; let him achieve new exploits, such as the priests declare at their libations. Indra hath taken and possessed all castles, like as one common husband doth his spouses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even thus have they declared him. Famed is Indra as Conqueror, sole distributer of treasures; Whose many succours come in close succession. May dear delightful benefits attend us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus, to bring help to men, Vasiṣṭha laudeth Indra, the peoples' Hero, at libation. Bestow upon us strength and wealth in thousands. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MEN call on Indra in the armed encounter that he may make the hymns they sing decisive. Hero, rejoicing in thy might, in combat give us a portion of the stall of cattle,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant, Indra Maghavan, invoked of many, to these my friends the strength which thou possessest. Thou, Maghavan, hast rent strong places open: unclose for us, Wise God, thy hidden bounty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: King of the living world, of men, is Indra, of all in varied form that earth containeth. Thence to the worshipper he giveth riches: may he enrich us also when we laud him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maghavan Indra, when we all invoke him, bountiful ever sendeth strength to aid us: Whose perfect guerdon, never failing, bringeth wealth to the men, to friends the thing they covet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Quick, Indra, give us room and way to riches, and let us bring thy mind to grant us treasures, That we may win us cars and Steeds and cattle. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME to our prayers, O Indra, thou who knowest: let thy Bay Steeds be yoked and guided hither. Though mortal men on every side invoke thee, still give thine ear to us, O All-impeller.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy greatness reacheth to our invocation, the sages' prayer which, Potent God, thou guardest. What time thy hand, O Mighty, holds the thunder, awful in strength thou hast become resistless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time thou drewest both world-halves together, like heroes led by thee who call each other- For thou wast born for strength and high dominion-then e’en the active overthrew the sluggish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Honour us in these present days, O Indra, for hostile men are making expiation. Our sin that sinless Varuṇa discovered, the Wondrous-Wise hath long ago forgiven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will address this liberal Lord, this Indra, that he may grant us gifts of ample riches, Best favourer of the singer's prayer and praises. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXIX Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS Soma hath been pressed for thee, O Indra: come hither, Lord of Bays, for this thou lovest. Drink of this fair, this well-effused libation: Maghavan, give us wealth when we implore thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us quickly with thy Bay Steeds, Hero, come to our prayer, accepting our devotion. Enjoy thyself aright at this libation, and listen thou unto the prayers we offer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What satisfaction do our hymns afford thee? When, Maghavan? Now let us do thee service. Hymns, only hymns, with love for thee, I weave thee: then hear, O Indra, these mine invocations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They, verily, were also human beings whom thou wast wont to hear, those earlier sages. Hence I, O Indra Maghavan, invoke thee: thou art our Providence, even as a Father.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will address this liberal Lord, this Indra, that he may grant us gifts of ample riches, Best favourer of the singer's prayer and praises. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH power and strength, O Mighty God, approach us: be the augmenter, Indra, of these riches; Strong Thunderer, Lord of men, for potent valour, for manly exploit and for high dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, worth invoking, in the din of battle, heroes invoke in fray for life and sunlight. Among all people thou art foremost fighter: give up our enemies to easy slaughter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When fair bright days shall dawn on us, O Indra, and thou shalt bring thy banner near in battle, Agni the Asura shall sit as Herald, calling Gods hither for our great good fortune.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine are we, Indra, thine, both these who praise thee, and those who give rich gifts, O God and Hero. Grant to our princes excellent protection, may they wax old and still be strong and happy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will address this liberal Lord, this Indra that he may grant us gifts of ample riches: Best favourer of the singer's prayer and praises. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING ye a song, to make him glad, to Indra, Lord of Tawny Steeds, The Soma-drinker, O my friends.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the Bounteous say the laud, and let us glorify, as men May do, the Giver of true gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Lord of boundless might, for us thou winnest strength and kine, Thou winnest gold for us, Good Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Faithful to thee we loudly sing, heroic Indra, songs to thee: Mark, O Good Lord, this act of ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us not up to man's reproach, to foeman's hateful calumny: In thee alone is all my strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art mine ample coat of mail, my Champion, Vṛtra-Slayer, thou: With thee for Friend I brave the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, great art thou whose conquering might two independent Powers confess. The Heaven, O India, and the Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So let the voice surround thee, which attends the Maruts on their way, Reaching thee with the rays of light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the ascending drops attain to thee, the Wondrous God, in heaven: Let all the folk bow down to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring to the Wise, the Great, who waxeth mighty, your offerings, and make ready your devotion; To many clans he goeth, man's controller.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra, the sublime, the far-pervading, have singers generated prayer and praises: The sages never violate his statutes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The choirs have stablished Indra King for ever, for victory, him whose anger is resistless: And, for the Bays' Lord, strengthened those he loveth. Next: HYMN XXXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET none, no, not thy worshippers, delay thee far away from us. Even from far away come thou unto our feast, or listen if already here.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For here, like flies on honey, these who pray to thee sit by the juice that they have poured. Wealth-craving singers have on Indra set their hope, as men set foot upon a car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Longing for wealth I call on him, the Thunderer with the strong right hand, As a son calleth on his sire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Soma juices, mixed with curd, have been expressed for Indra here. Come with thy Bay Steeds, Thunder-wielder, to our home, to drink them till they make thee glad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he whose ear is open hear us. He is asked for wealth: will he despise our prayer? Him who bestows at once a hundred thousand gifts none shall restrain when he would give.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The hero never checked by men hath gained his strength through Indra, he Who presses out and pours his deep libations forth, O Vṛtra-slayer, unto thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou dost drive the fighting men together be, thou Mighty One, the mighty's shield. May we divide the wealth of him whom thou hast slain: bring us, Unreachable, his goods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra, Soma-drinker, armed with thunder, press the Soma juice. Make ready your dressed meats: cause him to favour us. The Giver blesses him who gives.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grudge not, ye Soma pourers; stir you, pay the rites, for wealth, to the great Conqueror. Only the active conquers dwells in peace, and thrives: not for the niggard are the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No one hath overturned or stayed the car of him who freely gives. The man whom Indra and the Marut host defend comes to a stable full of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, that man when fighting shall obtain the spoil, whose strong defender thou wilt be. Be thou the gracious helper, Hero I of our cars, be thou the helper of our men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His portion is exceeding great like a victorious soldier's spoil. Him who is Indra, Lord of Bays, no foes subdue. He gives the Soma-pourer strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make for the Holy Gods a hymn that is not mean, but well-arranged and fair of form. Even many snares and bonds subdue not him who dwells with Indra through his sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, what mortal will attack the man who hath his wealth in thee? The strong will win the spoil on the decisive day through faith in thee, O Maghavan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In battles with the foe urge on our mighty ones who give the treasures dear to thee, And may we with our princes, Lord of Tawny Steeds! pass through all peril, led by thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine, Indra, is the lowest wealth, thou cherishest the mid-most wealth, Thou ever rulest all the highest: in the fray for cattle none resisteth thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art renowned as giving wealth to every one in all the battles that are fought. Craving protection, all these people of the earth, O Much-invoked, implore thy name.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If I, O Indra, were the Lord of riches ample as thine own, I should support the singer, God. who givest wealth! and not abandon him to woe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Each day would I enrich the man who sang my praise, in whatsoever place he were. No kinship is there better, Maghavan, than thine: a father even is no more.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Plenty for his true ally the active man will gain the spoil. Your Indra, Much-invoked, I bend with song, as bends a wright his wheel of solid wood.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A moral wins no riches by unworthy praise: wealth comes not to the niggard churl. Light is the task to give, O Maghavan, to one like me on the decisive day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like kine unmilked we call aloud, Hero, to thee, and sing thy praise, Looker on heavenly light, Lord of this moving world, Lord, Indra, of what moveth not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None other like to thee, of earth or of the heavens, hath been or ever will be born. Desiring horses, Indra Maghavan! and kine, as men of might we call on thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring, Indra, the Victorious Ones; bring, elder thou, the younger host. For, Maghavan, thou art rich in treasures from of old, and must be called in every fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive thou away our enemies, O Maghavan: make riches easy to be won. Be thou our good Protector in the strife for spoil: Cherisher of our friends be thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, give us wisdom as a sire gives wisdom to his sons. Guide us, O Much-invoked, in this our way may we still live and look upon the light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant that no mighty foes, unknown, malevolent, unhallowed, tread us to the ground. With thine assistance, Hero, may we ass through all the waters that are rul`ng down. Next: HYMN XXXIII Vasiṣṭha.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THESE who wear hair-knots on the right, the movers of holy thought, white-robed, have won me over. I warned the men, when from the grass I raised me, Not from afar can my Vasisthas help you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Soma they brought Indra from a distance, Over Vaisanta, from the strong libation. Indra preferred Vasisthas to the Soma pressed by the son of Vayata, Pasadyumna.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, verily, with these he crossed the river, in company with these he slaughtered Bheda. So in the fight with the Ten Kings, Vasisthas! did Indra help Sudās through your devotions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I gladly, men I with prayer prayed by our fathers have fixed your axle: ye shall not be injured: Since, when ye sang aloud the Sakvari verses, Vasisthas! ye invigorated Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like thirsty men they looked to heaven, in battle with the Ten Kings, surrounded and imploring. Then Indra heard Vasiṣṭha as he praised him, and gave the Trtsus ample room and freedom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like sticks and staves wherewith they drive the cattle, Stripped bare, the Bharatas were found defenceless: Vasiṣṭha then became their chief and leader: then widely. were the Trtsus' clans extended.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three fertilize the worlds with genial moisture: three noble Creatures cast a light before them. Three that give warmth to all attend the morning. All these have they discovered, these Vasisthas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like the Sun's growing glory is their splendour, and like the sea's is their unflathomed greatness. Their course is like the wind's. Your laud, Vasisthas, can never be attained by any other.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They with perceptions of the heart in secret resort to that which spreads a thousand branches. The Apsaras brought hither the Vasisthas wearing the vesture spun for them by Yama.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A form of lustre springing from the lightning wast thou, when Varuṇa and Mitra saw thee. Tliy one and only birth was then, Vasiṣṭha, when from thy stock Agastya brought thee hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born of their love for Urvasi, Vasiṣṭha thou, priest, art son of Varuṇa and Mitra; And as a fallen drop, in heavenly fervour, all the Gods laid thee on a lotus-blossorn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He thinker, knower both of earth and heaven, endowed with many a gift, bestowing thousands, Destined to wear the vesture spun by Yama, sprang from the Apsaras to life, Vasiṣṭha.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born at the sacrifice, urged by adorations, both with a common flow bedewed the pitcher. Then from the midst thereof there rose up Māna, and thence they say was born the sage Vasiṣṭha.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He brings the bearer of the laud and Sāman: first shall he speak bringing the stone for pressing. With grateful hearts in reverence approach him: to you, O Pratrdas, Vasiṣṭha cometh. Next: HYMN XXXIV Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY our divine and brilliant hymn go forth, like a swift chariot wrought and fashioned well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The waters listen as they flow along: they know the origin of heaven and earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, the broad waters swell their flood ior him: of him strong heroes think amid their foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Set ye for him the coursers to the pole: like Indra Thunderer is the Golden-armed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Arouse you, like the days, to sacrifice speed gladly like a traveller on the way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Go swift to battles, to the sacrifice: set up a flag, a hero for the folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Up from his strength hath risen as ’twere a light: it bears the load as earth bears living things.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, no demon I invoke the Gods: by law completing it, I form a hymn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Closely albout you lay your heavenly song, and send your voice to where the Gods abide.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa, Mighty, with a thousand eyes, beholds the paths wherein these rivers run.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, King of kings, the glory of the floods, o’er all that liveth hath resistless sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he assist us among all the tribes, and make the envier's praise devoid of light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the foes' threatening arrow pass us by: may he put far from us our bodies' sin.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, oblation-cater, through our prayers aid us: to him our dearest laud is brought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accordant with the Gods choose for our Friend the Waters’ Child: may he be good to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With lauds I sing the Dragon born of floods: he sits beneath the streams in middle air.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ne’er may the Dragon of the Deep harm us: ne’er fail this faithful servant's sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To these our heroes may they grant renown: may pious men march boldly on to wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Leading great hosts, with fierce attacks of these, they burn their foes as the Sun burns the earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time our wives draw near to us, may he, left-handed Tvaṣṭar, give us hero sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Tvaṣṭar find our hymn acceptable, and may Aramati, seeking wealth, be ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May they who lavish gifts bestow those treasures: may Rodasī and Varuṇānī listen. May he, with the Varūtrīs, be our refuge, may bountiful Tvaṣṭar give us store of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may rich Mountains and the liberal Waters, so may all Herbs that grow on ground, and Heaven, And Earth accordant with the Forest-Sovrans, and both the World-halves round about protect us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To this may both the wide Worlds lend approval, and Varuṇa in heaven, whose Friend is Indra. May all the Maruts give consent, the Victors, that we may hold great wealth in firm possession.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra, Varuṇa, Mitra, and Agni, Waters, Herbs, Trees accept the praise we offer. May we find refuge in the Marut's bosom. Protect us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXXV. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BEFRIEND us with their aids Indra and Agni, Indra and Varuṇa who receive oblations! Indra and Soma give health, strength and comfort, Indra and Pūṣan be our help in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Auspicious Friends to us be Bhaga, Sathsa, auspicious be Purandhi aid all Riches; The blessing of the true and well-conducted, and Aryaman in many forms apparent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kind unto us he Maker and Sustainer, and the far-reaching Pair with God-like natures. Auspicious unto us be Earth and Heaven, the Mountain, and the Gods’ fair invocations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Favour us Agni with his face of splendour, and Varuva and Mitra and the Aśvins. Favour us noble actions of the pious, impetuous vita blow on us with favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Early invoked, may Heaven and Earth be friendly, and Air's mid-region good for us to look on. To us may Herbs and Forest-Trees be gracious, gracious the Lord Victorious of the region.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be the God Indra with the Vasus friendly, and, with Ādityas, Varuṇa who blesseth. Kind, with the Rudras, be the Healer Rudra, and, with the Dames, may Tvaṣṭar kindly listen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blest unto us be Soma, and devotions, blest be the Sacrifice, the Stones for pressing. Blest be the fixing of the sacred Pillars, blest be the tender Grass and blest the Altar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the far-seeing Sun rise up to bless us: be the four Quarters of the sky auspicious. Auspicious be the firmly-seated Mountains, auspicious be the Rivers and the Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Adid through holy works be gracioas, and may the Maruts, loud in song, be friendly. May Viṣṇu give felicity, and Pūṣan, the Air that cherisheth our life, and Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Prosper us Savitar, the God who rescues, and let the radiant Mornings be propitious. Auspicious to all creatures be Parjanya, auspicious be the field's benign Protector.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May all the fellowship of Gods befriend us, Sarasvatī, with Holy Thoughts, be gracious. Friendly be they, the Liberal Ones who seek us, yea, those who dwell in heaven, on earth, in waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the great Lords of Truth protect and aid us: blest to us be our horses and our cattle. Kind be the pious skilful-handed Ṛbhus, kind be the Fathers at our invocations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Aja-Ekapād, the God, be gracious, gracious the Dragon of the Deep, and Ocean. Gracious be he the swelling Child of Waters, gracious be Pṛśni who hath Gods to guard her.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may the Rudras, Vasus, and Ādityas accept the new hymn which we now are making. May all the Holy Ones of earth and heaven, and the Cow's offipring hear our invocation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who of Holy Gods are very holy, Immortal, knowing Law, whom man must worship,— May these to-day give us broad paths to travel. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXXVI. Viśvedevas

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET the prayer issue from the seat of Order, for Sūrya with his beams hath loosed the cattle. With lofty ridges earth is far extended, and Agni's flame hath lit the spacious surface.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Asuras, O Varuṇa and Mitra, this hymn to you, like food, anew I offer. One of you is a strong unerring Leader, and Mitra, speaking, stirreth men to labour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The movements of the gliding wind come hither: like cows, the springs are filled to overflowing. Born in the station e’en of lofty heaven the Bull hath loudly bellowed in this region.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May I bring hither with my song, O Indra, wise Aryaman who yokes thy dear Bay Horses, Voracious, with thy noble car, O Hero, him who defeats the wrath of the malicious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In their own place of sacrifice adorers worship to gain long life and win his friendship. He hath poured food on men when they have praised him; be this, the dearest reverence, paid to Rudra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Coming together, glorious, loudly roaring - Sarasvatī, Mother of Floods, the seventh- With copious milk, with fair streams, strongly flowing, full swelling with the volume of their water;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And may the mighty Maruts, too, rejoicing, aid our devotion and protect our offspring. Let not swift-moving Aksara neglect us: they have increased our own appropriate riches,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring ye the great Aramati before you, and Pūṣan as the Hero of the synod, Bhaga who looks upon this hymn with favour, and, as our strength, the bountiful Purandbi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this our song of praise reach you, O Maruts, and Viṣṇu guardian of the future infant. May they vouchsafe the singer strength for offspring. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXXVII. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET your best-bearing car that must be lauded, ne’er injured, bring you Vājas and Ṛbhukṣans. Fill you, fair-helmeted! with mighty Soma, thrice-mixed, at our libations to delight you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who behold the light of heaven, Ṛbhukṣans, give our rich patrons unmolested riches. Drink, heavenly-natured. at our sacrifices, and give us bounties for the hymns we sing you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O Bounteous One, art used to giving, at parting treasure whether small or ample. Filled full are both thine arms with great possessions: thy goodness keeps thee not from granting riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, high-famed, as Vāja and Ṛbhukṣans, thou goest working, singing to the dwelling. Lord of Bay Steeds, this day may we Vasisthas offer our prayers to thee and bring oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou winnest swift advancement for thy servant, through hymns, Lord of Bay Steeds, which thou hast favoured. For thee with friendly succour have we battled, and when, O Indra, wilt thou grant us riches?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To us thy priests a home, as ’twere, thou givest: when, Indra wilt thou recognize our praises? May thy strong Steed, through our ancestral worship, bring food and wealth with heroes to our dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Though Nirrti the Goddess reigneth round him, Autumns with food in plenty come to Indra. With three close Friends to length of days he cometh, he whom men let not rest at home in quiet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Promise us gifts, O Savitar: may riches come unto us in Parvata's full bounty. May the Celestial Guardian still attend us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XXXVIII. Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ON high hath Savitar, this God, extended the golden lustre which he spreads around him. Now, now must Bhaga be invoked by mortals, Lord of great riches who distributes treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rise up, O Savitar whose hands are golden, and hear this man while sacrifice is offered, Spreading afar thy broad and wide effulgence, and bringing mortal men the food that feeds them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Savitar the God he hymned with praises, to whom the Vasus, even, all sing glory. Sweet be our lauds to him whose due is worship: may he with all protection guard our princes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even he whom Aditi the Goddess praises, rejoicing in God Savitar's incitement: Even he who praise the high imperial Rulers, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, sing in concert.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
