text: They who come emulous to our oblation, dispensing bounty, from the earth and heaven. May they and Ahibudhnya hear our calling: guard us Varūtrī with the Ekadhenus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This may the Lord of Life, entreated, grant us,—the wealth which Savitar the God possesses. The mighty calls on Bhaga for protection, on Bhaga calls the weak to give him riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bless us the Vajins when we call, while slowly they move, strong Singers, to the Gods’ assembly. Crushing the wolf, the serpent, and the demons, may they completely banish all affliction.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deep-skilled in Law eternal, deathless, Singers, O Vajins, help us in each fray for booty. Drink of this meath, he satisfied, be joyful: then go on paths which Gods are wont to travel. Next: HYMN XXXIX Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI, erect, hath shown enriching favour: the flame goes forward to the Gods’ assembly. Like car-borne men the stones their path have chosen: let the priest, quickened, celebrate our worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soft to the tread, their sacred grass is scattered: these go like Kings amid the band around them, At the folks early call on Night and Morning,—Vāyu, and Pūṣan with his team, to bless us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here on their path the noble Gods proceeded: in the wide firmament the Beauteous decked them. Bend your way hither, ye who travel widely: hear this our envoy who hath gone to meet you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For they are holy aids at sacrifices: all Gods approach the place of congregation. Bring these, desirous, to our worship, Agni, swift the Nisatyas, Bhaga, and Purandhi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, to these men's hymns, from earth, from heaven, bring Mitra, Varuṇa, Indra, and Agni, And Aryaman, and Aditi, and Viṣṇu. Sarasvatī be joyful, and the Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as the holy wish, the gift is offered: may he, unsated, come when men desire him. Give never-failing ever-conquering riches: with Gods for our allies may we be victors.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now have both worlds been praised by the Vasisthas; and holy Mitra, Varuṇa, and Agni. May they, bright Deities, make our song supremest. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XL. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BE gathered all the audience of the synod: let us begin their praise whose course is rapid. Whate’er God Savitar this day produces, may we be where the Wealthy One distributes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This, dealt from heaven ' may both the Worlds vouchsafe us, and Varuṇa, Indra, Aryaman, and Mitra. May Goddess Aditi assign us riches, Vāyu and Bhaga make them ours for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong be the man and full of power, O Maruts, whom ye, borne on by spotted coursers, favour. Him, too, Sarasvatī and Agni further, and there is none to rob him of his riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Varuṇa is guide of Law, he, Mitra, and Aryaman, the Kings, our work have finished. Divine and foeless Aditi quickly listens. May these deliver us unharmed from trouble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With offerings I propitiate the branches of this swift-moving God, the bounteous Viṣṇu. Hence Rudra gained his Rudra-strength: O Aśvins, ye sought the house that hath celestial viands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be not thou angry here, O glowing Pūṣan, for what Varūtrī and the Bounteous gave us. May the swift-moving Gods protect and bless us, and Vāta send us rain, wha wanders round us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now have both worlds been praised by the Vasisthas, and holy Mitra, Varuṇa, and Agni. May they, bright Deities, make our song supremest. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLI. Bhaga.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI at dawn, and Indra we invoke at dawn, and Varuṇa and Mitra, and the Aśvins twain. Bhaga at dawn, Pūṣan, and Brahmaṇaspati, Soma at dawn, Rudra we will invoke at dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We will invoke strong, early-conquering Bhaga, the Son of Aditi, the great supporter: Thinking of whom, the poor, yea, even the mighty, even the King himself says, Give me Bhaga.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bhaga our guide, Bhaga whose gifts are faithful, favour this song, and give us wealth, O Bhaga. Bhaga, augment our store of kine and horses, Bhaga, may we be rich in men and heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may felicity be ours at present, and when the day approaches, and at noontide; And may we still, O Bounteous One, at sunset be happy in the Deities' loving-kindness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Bhaga verily be bliss-bestower, and through him, Gods! may happiness attend us. As such, O Bhaga, all with might invoke thee: as such be thou our Champion here, O Bhaga.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To this our worship may all Dawns incline them, and come to the pure place like Dadhikrāvan. As strong steeds draw a chariot may they bring us hitherward Bhaga who discovers treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May blessed Mornings dawn on us for ever, with wealth of kine, of horses, and of heroes, Streaming with all abundance, pouring fatness. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLII Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET Brahmans and Aṅgirases come forward, and let the roar of cloudy heaven surround us. Loud low the Milch-kine swimming in the waters: set be the stones that grace our holy service.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fair, Agni, is thy long-known path to travel: yoke for the juice tfiy bay, thy ruddy horses, Or red steeds, Hero-bearing, for the chamber. Seated, I call the Deities' generations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They glorify your sacrifice with worship, yet the glad Priest near them is left unequalled. Bring the Gods hither, thou of many aspects: turn hitherward Aramati the Holy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Guest hath made himself apparent, at ease reclining in the rich man's dwelling, Agni, well-pleased, well-placed within the chamber gives to a house like this wealth worth the choosing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept this sacrifice of ours, O Agni; glorify it with Indra and the Maruts. Here on our grass let Night and Dawn be seated: bring longing Varuṇa and Mitra hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus hath Vasiṣṭha praised victorious Agni, yearning for wealth that giveth all subsistence. May he bestow on us food, strength, and riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLIII Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING out the pious at your sacrifices to move with adorations Earth and Heaven- The Holy Singers, whose unmatched devotions, like a tree's branches, part in all directions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let sacrifice proceed like some fleet courser: with one accord lift ye on high the ladles. Strew sacred grass meet for the solenm service: bright flames that love the Gods have mounted upward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like babes in arms reposing on their mother, let the Gods sit upon the grass's summit. Let general fire make bright the flame of worship: scorn us not, Agni, in the Gods’ assembly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gladly the Gods have let themselves be honoured, milking the copious streams of holy Order. The highest might to-day is yours, the Vasits': come ye, as many as ye are, one-minded.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Agni, send us wealth among the people: may we be closely knit to thee, O Victor, Unharmed, and rich, and taking joy together. Preserve us evermore, ye ods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLIV. Dadhikrās.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I CALL on Dadhikrās, the first, to give you aid, the Aśvins, Bhaga, Dawn, and Agni kindled well, Indra, and Viṣṇu, Pūṣan, Brahmaṇaspati, Ādityas, Heaven and Earth, the Waters, and the Light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, rising, to the sacrifice we hasten, awaking Dadhikrās with adorations. Seating on sacred grass the Goddess Iḷā. let us invoke the sage swift-hearing Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While I am thus arousing Dadhikrāvan I speak to Agni, Earth, and Dawn, and Sūrya, The red, the brown of Varuṇa ever mindful: may they ward off from us all grief and trouble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Foremost is Dadhikrāvan, vigorous courser; in forefront of the cars, his way he knoweth, Closely allied with Sūrya and with Morning, Ādityas, and Aṅgirases, and Vasus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Dadhikrās prepare the way we travel that we may pass along the path of Order. May Agni bear us, and the Heavenly Army: hear us all Mighty Ones whom none deceiveth. Next: HYMN XLV. Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY the God Savitar, rich in goodly treasures, filling the region, borne by steeds, come hither, In his hand holding much that makes men happy, lulling to slumber and arousing creatures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Golden, sublime, and easy in their motion, his arms extend unto the bounds of heaven. Now shall that mightiness of his he lauded: even Sūrya yields to him in active vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this God Savitar, the Strong and Mighty, the Lord of precious wealth, vouchsafe us treasures. May he, advancing his far-spreading lustre, bestow on us the food that feedeth mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These songs praise Savitar whose tongue is pleasant, praise him whose arms are full, whose hands are lovely. High vital strength, and manifold, may he grant us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLVI. Rudra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Rudra bring these songs, whose bow is firm and strong, the self-dependent God with swiftly-flying shafts, The Wise, the Conqueror whom none may overcome, armed with sharp-pointed weapons: may he hear our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He through his lordship thinks on beings of the earth, on heavenly beings through his high imperial sway. Come willingly to our doors that gladly welcome thee, and heal all sickness, Rudra., in our families.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May thy bright arrow which, shot down by thee from heaven, flieth upon the earth, pass us uninjured by. Thou, very gracious God, hast thousand medicines: inflict no evil on our sons or progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay us not, nor abandon us, O Rudra let not thy noose, when thou art angry, seize us. Give us trimmed grass and fame among the living. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLVII. Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY we obtain this day from you, O Waters, that wave of pure refreshment, which the pious Made erst the special beverage of Indra, bright, stainless, rich in sweets and dropping fatness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Floods' Offspring, he whose course is rapid, protect that wave most rich in sweets, O Waters, That shall make Indra and the Vasus joyful. This may we gain from you to-day, we pious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All-purifying, joying in their nature, to paths of Gods the Goddesses move onward. They never violate the laws of Indra. Present the oil-rich offering to the Rivers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom Sūrya with his bright beams hath attracted, and Indra dug the path for them to travel, May these Streams give us ample room and freedom. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLVIII. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YE liberal Heroes, Vājas and Ṛbhukṣans, come and delight you with our flowing Soma. May your strength, Vibhus, as ye come to meet us, turn hitherward your car that brings men profit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we as Ṛbhu with your Ṛbhus conquer strength with our strength, as Vibhus with the Vibhus. May Vāja aid us in the fight for booty, and helped by Indra may we quell the foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For they rule many tribes with high dominion, and conquer all their foes in close encounter. May Indra, Vibhvan, Vāja, and Ṛbhukṣan destroy by turns the wicked foeman's valour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, Deities, give us ample room and freedom: be all of you, one-minded, our protection. So let the Vasus grant us strength and vigour. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XLIX. Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FORTH from the middle of the flood the Waters-their chief the Sea-flow cleansing, never sleeping. Indra, the Bull, the Thunderer, dug their channels: here let those Waters, Goddesses, protect me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Waters which come from heaven, or those that wander dug from the earth, or flowing free by nature, Bright, purifying, speeding to the Ocean, here let those Waters. Goddesses, protect me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those amid whom goes Varuṇa the Sovran, he who discriminates men's truth and falsehood- Distilling meath, the bright, the purifying, here let those Waters, Goddesses, protect me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They from whom Varuṇa the King, and Soma, and all the Deities drink strength and vigour, They into whom Vaiśvānara Agni entered, here let those Waters, Goddesses, protect Me. Next: HYMN L. Various Deities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O MITRA-VARUNA, guard and protect me here: let not that come to me which nests within and swells. I drive afar the scorpion hateful to the sight: let not the winding worm touch me and wound my foot.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eruption that appears upon the twofold joints, and that which overspreads the ankles and the knees, May the refulgent Agni banish far away let not the winding worm touch me and wound my foot.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The poison that is formed upon the Salmali, that which is found in streams, that which the plants produce, All this may all the Gods banish and drive away: let not the winding worm touch me and wound my foot.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The steep declivities, the valleys, and the heights, the channels full of water, and the waterless- May those who swell with water, gracious Goddesses, never afflict us with the Sipada disease, may all the rivers keep us free from Simida. Next: HYMN LI. Ādityas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THROUGH the Ādityas’ most auspicious shelter, through their most recent succour may we conquer. May they, the Mighty, giving ear, establish this sacrifice, to make us free and sinless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Aditi rejoice and the Ādityas, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, most righteous. May they, the Guardians of the world, protect us, and, to show favour, drink this day our Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All Universal Deities, the Maruts, all the Ādityas, yea, and all the Ṛbhus, Indra, and Agni, and the Aśvins, lauded. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LII. Ādityas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY we be free from every bond, Ādityas! a castle among Gods and men, ye Vasus. Winning, may we win Varuṇa and Mitra, and, being, may we be, O Earth and Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Varuṇa and Mitra grant this blessing, our Guardians, shelter to our seed and offspring. Let us not suffer for another's trespass. nor do the thing that ye, O Vasus, punish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The ever-prompt Aṅgirases, imploring riches from Savitar the God, obtained them. So may our Father who is great and holy, and all the Gods, accordant, grant this favour. Next: HYMN LIII. Heaven and Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AS priest with solemn rites and adorations I worship Heaven and Earth, the High and Holy. To them, great Parents of the Gods, have sages of ancient time, singing, assigned precedence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With newest hymns set in the seat of Order, those the Two Parents, born before all others, Come, Heaven and Earth, with the Celestial People, hither to us, for strong is your protection.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Heaven and Earth, ye hold in your possession full many a treasure for the liberal giver. Grant us that wealth which comes in free abundance. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LIV. Vastospati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ACKNOWLEDGE us, O Guardian of the Homestead: bring no disease, and give us happy entrance. Whate’er we ask of thee, be pleased to grant it, and prosper thou quadrupeds and bipeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Protector of the Home, be our promoter: increase our wealth in kine and steeds, O Indu. May we be ever-youthful in thy friendship: be pleased in us as in his sons a father.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through thy dear fellowship that bringeth welfare, may we be victors, Guardian of the Dwelling! Protect our happiness in rest and labour. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LV. Vastospati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: VASTOSPATI, who killest all disease and wearest every form, Be an auspicious Friend to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, O bright Son of Saramā, thou showest, tawny-hued! thy teeth, They gleam like lances' points within thy mouth when thou wouldst bite; go thou to steep.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Saramā's Son, retrace thy way: bark at the robber and the thief. At Indra's singers barkest thou? Why dust thou seek to terrify us? Go to sleep.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be on thy guard against the boar, and let the boar beware of thee. At Indra's singers barkest thou? Why dost thou seek to terrify us? Go to sleep.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sleep mother, let the father sleep, sleep dog and master of the house. Let all the kinsmen sleep, sleep all the people who are round about.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who sits, the man who walks, and whosoever looks on us, Of these we closely shut the eyes, even as we closely shut this house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bull who hath a thousand horns, who rises up from out the sea,— By him the Strong and Mighty One we lull and make the people sleep.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The women sleeping in the court, lying without, or stretched on beds, The matrons with their odorous sweetsthese, one and all, we lull to sleep. Next: HYMN LVI. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wno are these radiant men in serried rank, Rudra's young heroes borne by noble steeds?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Verily no one knoweth whence they sprang: they, and they only, know each other's birth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They strew each other with their blasts, these Hawks: they strove together, roaring like the wind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A sage was he who knew these mysteries, what in her udder mighty Pṛśni bore.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ever victorious, through the Maruts, be this band of Heroes, nursing manly strength,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most bright in splendour, flectest on their way, close-knit to glory, strong with varied power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, mighty is your power and firm your strength: so, potent, with the Maruts, be the band.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright is your spirit, wrathful are your minds: your bold troop's minstrel is like one inspired.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ever avert your blazing shaft from us, and let not your displeasure reach us here

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your dear names, conquering Maruts, we invoke, calling aloud till we are satisfied.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well-armed, impetuous in their haste, they deck themselves, their forms, with oblations: to you, the pure, ornaments made of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pure, Maruts, pure yourselves, are your oblations: to you, the pure, pure sacrifice I offer. By Law they came to truth, the Law's observers, bright by their birth, and pure, and sanctifying.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your rings, O Maruts, rest upon your shoulders, and chains of gold are twined upon your bosoms. Gleaming with drops of rain, like lightning-flashes, after your wont ye whirl about your weapons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wide in the depth of air spread forth your glories, far, most adorable, ye bear your titles. Maruts, accept this thousandfold allotment of household sacrifice and household treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If, Maruts, ye regard the praise recited here at this mighty singer invocation, Vouchsafe us quickly wealth with noble heroes, wealth which no man uho hateth us may injure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts, fleet as coursers, while they deck them like youths spectators of a festal meeting, Linger, like beauteous colts, about the dwelling, like frisking calves, these who pour down the water.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may the Maruts help us and be gracious, bringing free room to lovely Earth and Heaven. Far be your bolt that slayeth men and cattle. Ye Vasus, turn yourselves to us with blessings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The priest, when seated, loudly calls you, Maruts, praising in song your universal bounty. He, Bulls! who hath so much in his possession, free from duplicity, with hymns invokes you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Maruts bring the swift man to a stand-still, and strength with mightier strength they break and humble These guard the singer from the man who hates him and lay their sore displeasure on the wicked.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Maruts rouse even the poor and needy: the Vasus love him as an active champion. Drive to a distance, O ye Bulls, the darkness: give us full store of children and descendants.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never, O Maruts, may we lose your bounty, nor, car-borne Lords! be hitidmost when ye deal it. Give us a share in that delightful treasure, the genuine wealth that, Bulls! is your possession.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the men in fury rush together for running streams, for pastures, and for houses. Then, O ye Maruts, ye who spring from Rudra, be our protectors in the strife with foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Full many a deed ye did for our forefathers worthy of lauds which, even of old, they sang you. lle strong man, with the Maruts, wins in battle, the charger, with the Maruts, gains the booty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ours, O ye Maruts, be the vigorous Hero, the Lord Divine of men, the strong Sustainer, With whom to fair lands we may cross the waters, and dwell in our own home with you beside us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra, Mitra, Varuṇa and Agni, Waters, and Plants, and Trees accept our praises. May we find shelter in the Marut's bosom. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LVII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YEA, through the power of your sweet juice, ye Holy! the Marut host is glad at sacrifices. They cause even spacious heaven and earth to tremble, they make the spring flow when they come, the Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts watch the man who sings their praises, promoters of the thought of him who worships. Seat you on sacred grass in our assembly, this day, with friendly minds, to share the banquet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No others gleam so brightly as these Maruts with their own forms, their golden gauds, their weapons. With all adornments, decking earth and heaven, they heighten, for bright show, their common splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far from us be your blazing dart, O Maruts, when we, through human frailty, sin against you. Let us not he exposed to that, ye Holy! May your most loving favour still attend us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May even what we have done delight the Maruts, the blameless Ones, the bright, the purifying. Further us, O ye Holy, with your kindness: advance us mightily that we may prosper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And may the Maruts, praised by all their titles, Heroes, enjoy the taste of our oblations. Give us of Amṛta for the sake of offspring: awake the excellent fair stores of riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, ye Maruts, praised, with all your succours, with all felicity come to our princes, Who, of themselves, a hundredfold increase us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LVIII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING to the troop that pours down rain in common, the Mighty Company of celestial nature. They make the world-halves tremble with their greatness: from depths of earth and sky they reach to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, your birth, Maruts, was with wild commotion, ye who move swiftly, fierce in wrath, terrific. Ye all-surpassing in your might and vigour, each looker on the light fears at your coming.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give ample vital power unto our princes let our fair praises gratify the Maruts. As the way travelled helpeth people onward, so further us with your delightful succours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your favoured singer counts his wealth by hundreds: the strong steed whom ye favour wins a thousand. The Sovran whom ye aid destroys the foeman. May this your gift, ye Shakers, be distinguished.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call, as such, the Sons of bounteous Rudra: will not the Maruts turn again to us-ward? What secret sin or open stirs their anger, that we implore the Swift Ones to forgive us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This eulogy of the Bounteous hath been spoken: accept, ye Maruts, this our hymn of praises. Ye Bulls, keep those who hate us at a distance. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LIX. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHOMSO ye rescue here and there, whomso ye guide, O Deities, To him give shelter, Agni, Mitra, Varuṇa, ye Maruts, and thou Aryaman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through your kind favour, Gods, on some auspicious day, the worshipper subdues his foes. That man increases home and strengthening ample food who brings you offerings as ye list.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vasiṣṭha will not overlook the lowliest one among you all. O Maruts, of our Soma juice effused to-day drink all of you with eager haste.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your succour in the battle injures not the man to whom ye, Heroes, grant your gifts. May your most recent favour turn to us again. Come quickly, ye who fain would drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hitherward to drink the juice, O ye whose bounties give you joy. These offerings are for you, these, Maruts, I present. Go not to any place but this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sit on our sacred grass, be graciously inclined to give the wealth for which we long, To take delight, ye Maruts, Friends of all, with Svāhā, in sweet Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Decking the beauty of their forms in secret the Swans with purple backs have flown down hither. Around me all the Company hath settled, like joyous Heroes glad in our libation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maruts, the man whose wrath is hard to master, he who would slay us ere we think, O Vasus, May he be tangled in the toils of mischief; smite ye him down with your most flaming weapon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, ye consuming Gods, enjoy this offering brought for you, To help us, ye who slay the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sharers of household sacrifice, come, Maruts, stay not far away, That ye may help us, Bounteous Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, Self-strong Maruts, yea, even here. ye Sages with your sunbright skins I dedicate your sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tryambaka we worship, sweet augmenter of prosperity. As from its stem the cucumber, so may I be released from death, not reft of immortality. Next: HYMN LX. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHEN thou, O Sun, this day, arising sinless, shalt speak the truth to Varuṇa and Mitra, O Aditi, may all the Deities love us, and thou, O Aryaman, while we are singing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Looking on man, O Varuṇa and Mitra, this Sun ascendeth up by both the pathways, Guardian of all things fixt, of all that moveth, beholding good and evil acts of mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He from their home hath yoked the Seven gold Coursers who, dropping oil and fatness, carry Sūrya. Yours, Varuṇa and Mitra, he surveyeth the worlds and living creatures like a herdsman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your coursers rich in store of sweets have mounted: to the bright ocean Sūrya hath ascended, For whom the Ādityas make his pathway ready, Aryaman, Mitra, Varuṇa, accordant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For these, even Aryaman, Varuṇa and Mitra, are the chastisers of all guile and falsehood. These, Aditi's Sons, infallible and mighty, have waxen in the home of law Eternal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These, Mitra, Varuṇa whom none deceiveth, with great power quicken even the fool to wisdom, And, wakening, moreover, thoughtful insight, lead it by easy paths o’er grief and trouble.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They ever vigilant, with eyes that close not, caring for heaven and earth, lead on the thoughtless. Even in the river's bed there is a shallow. across this broad expanse may they conduct us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Aditi and Varuṇa and Mitra, like guardians, give Sudās their friendly shelter, Granting him sons and lineal succession, let us not, bold ones! move the Gods to anger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he with ofierings purify the altar from any stains of Varuṇa's reviler. Aryaman save us us all those who hate us: give room and freedom to Sudās, ye Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hid from our eyes is their resplendent meeting: by their mysterious might they hold dominion. Heroes! we cry trembling in fear before you, even in the greatness of your power have mercy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who wins favour for his prayer by worship, that he may gain him strength and highest riches, That good man's mind the Mighty Ones will follow: they have brought comfort to his spacious dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This priestly task, Gods! Varuṇa and Mitra! hath been performed for you at sacrifices. Convey us safely over every peril. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXI. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O VARUNA and Mitra, Sūrya spreading the beauteous light of you Twain Gods ariseth. He who beholdetb all existing creatures observetb well the zeal that is in mortals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The holy sage, renowned afar, directeth his hymns to you, O Varuṇa and Mitra,— He whose devotions, sapient Gods, ye favour so that ye fill, as ’twere, with power his autumns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From the wide earth, O Varuṇa and Mitra from the great lofty heaven, ye, Bounteous Givers, - Have in the fields and houses set your warder-, who visit every spot and watch unceasing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I praise the strength of Varuṇa and Mitra that strength, by mightiness, keeps both worlds asunder. Heroless pass the months of the ungodly he who loves sacrifice makes his home enduring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Steers, all infallible are these your people in whom no wondrous thing is seen, no worship. Guile follows close the men who are untruthful: no secrets may be hidden from your knowledge.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I will exalt your sacrifice with homage: as priest, I, Mitra-Varuṇa, invoke you. May these new hymns and prayers that I have fashioned delight you to the profit of the singer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This priestly task, Gods! Varuṇa and Mitra! hath been performed for you at sacrifices. Convey us safely over every peril. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXII. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SURYA hath sent aloft his beams of splendour o’er all the tribes of men in countless places. Together with the heaven he shines apparent, formed by his Makers well with power and wisdom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So hast thou mounted up before us, Sūrya, through these our praises, with fleet dappled horses. Declare us free from all offence to Mitra, and Varuṇa, and Aryaman, and Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May holy Agni, Varuṇa, and Mitra send down their riches upon us in thousands. May they, the Bright Ones, make our praise-song perfect, and, when we laud them, grant us all our wishes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O undivided Heaven and Earth, preserve us, us, Lofty Ones! your nobIy-born descendants. Let us not anger Varuṇa, nor Vāyu, nor him, the dearest Friend of mortals, Mitra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Stretch forth your arms and let our lives be lengthened: with fatness dew the pastures of our cattle. Ye Youthful, make us famed among the people: hear, Mitra-Varuṇa, these mine invocations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now Mitra, Varuṇa, Aryaman vouchsafe us freedom and room, for us and for our children. May we find paths all fair and good to travel. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXIII. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COMMON to all mankind, auspicious Sūrya, he who beholdeth all, is mounting upward; The God, the eye of Varuṇa and Mitra, who rolled up darkness like a piece of leather.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sūrya's great ensign, restless as the billow, that urgeth men to action, is advancing: Onward he still would roll the wheel well-rounded, which Etaśa, harnessed to the car-pole, moveth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Refulgent from the bosom of the Mornings, he in Whom singers take delight ascendeth. This Savitar, God, is my chief joy and pleasure, who breaketh not the universal statute.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Golden, far-seeing, from the heaven he riseth: far is his goal, he hasteth on resplendent. Men, verily, inspirited by Sūrya speed to their aims and do the work assigned them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where the irrunortals have prepared his pathway he flieth through the region like a falcon. With homage and oblations will we serve you, O Mitra-Varuṇa, when the Sun hath risen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now Mitra, Varuṇa, Aryaman vouchsafe us freedom and room, for us and for our children. May we find paths all fair and good to travel. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXIV. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YE Twain who rule, in heaven and earth, the region, clothed be your clouds in robes of oil and fatness. May the imperial Varuṇa, and Mitra, and high-born Aryaman accept our presents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kings, guards of rrtighty everlasting Order, come hitherward, ye Princes, Lords of Rivers. Send us from heaven, O Varuṇa and Mitra, rain and sweet food, ye who pour down your bounties.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the dear God, and Varuṇa and Mitra conduct us by the most effective pathways, That foes may say unto Sudās our chieftain, May, we, too, joy in food with Gods to guard us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who hath wrought for you this car in spirit, who makes the song rise upward and sustains it, Bedew with fatness, Varuṇa nd Mitra ye Kings, make glad the pleasant dwelling-places.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To you this laud, O Varuṇa and Mitra is offered like bright Soma juice to Vāyu. Favour our songs of praise, wake thought and spirit. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXV. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH hymns I call you, when the Sun hath risen, Mitra, and Varuṇa whose thoughts are holy, Whose Power Divine, supreme and everlasting, comes with good heed at each man's supplication.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For they are Asuras of Gods, the friendly make, both of you, our lands exceeding fruitful. May we obtain you, Varuṇa and Mitra, wherever Heaven and Earth and days may bless us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bonds of the sinner, they bear many nooses: the wicked mortal hardly may escape them. Varuṇa-Mitra, may your path of Order bear us o’er trouble as a boat o’er waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, taste our offering, Varuṇa and Mitra: bedew our pasture wil sweet food and fatness. Pour down in plenty here upon the people the choicest of your fair celestial water.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To you this laud, O Varuṇa and Mitra, is offered, like bright Soma juice to Vāyu. Favour our songs of praise, wake thought and spirit. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXVI Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET our strong hymn of praise go forth, the laud of Mitra-Varuṇa, With homage to that high-born Pair;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Two exceeding wise, the Sons of Dakṣa, whom the gods ordained For lordship, excellently great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such, Guardians of our homes and us, O Mitra-Varuṇa, fulfil The thoughts of those who sing your praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So when the Sun hath risen to-day, may sinless Mitra, Aryaman, Bhaga, and Savitar sendus forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this our home be guarded well forward, ye Bounteous, on the way, Who bear us safely o’er distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And those Self-reigning, Aditi, whose statute is inviolate, The Kings who rule a vast domain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soon as the Sun hath risen, to you, to Mitra-Varuṇa, I sing, And Aryarnan who slays the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With wealth of gold may this my song bring unmolested power and might, And, Brahmans, gain the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be thine, God Varuṇa, and with our princes, Mitra, thine. Food and Heaven's light will we obtain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Many are they who strengthen Law, Sun-eyed, with Agni for their tongue, They who direct the three great gatherings with their thoughts, yea, all things with surpassing might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who have stablished year and month and then the day, night, sacrifice and holy verse, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryarnan, the Kings, have won dominion which none else may gain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So at the rising of the Sun we think of you with hymns to-day, Even as Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman deserve: ye are the charioteers of Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: True to Law, born in Law the strengtheners of Law, terrible, haters of the false, In their felicity which gives the best defence may we men and our princes dwell.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Uprises, on the slope of heaven, that marvel that attracts die sight As swift celestial Etaśa bears it away, prepared for every eye to see.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of each single head, of fixt and moving things, equally through the whole expanse, The Seven sister Bays bear Sūrya on his car, to bring us wealth and happiness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred autumns may we see that bright Eye, God-ordained, arise A hundred autumns may we live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Infallible through your wisdom, come hither, resplendent Varuṇa, And Mitra, to the Soma draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come as the laws of Heaven ordain, Varuṇa, Mitra, void of guile: Press near and drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Mitra, Varuṇa, accept, Heroes, our sacrificial gift: Drink Soma, ye who strengthen Law. Next: HYMN LXVII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I WITH a holy heart that brings oblation will sing forth praise to meet your car, ye Princes, Which, Much-desired! hath wakened as your envoy. I call you hither as a son his parents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Brightly hath Agni shone by us enkindled: the limits even of darkness were apparent. Eastward is seen the Banner of the Morning, the Banner born to give Heaven's Daughter glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With hymns the deft priest is about you, Aśvins, the eloquent priest attends you now, Nāsatyas. Come by the paths that ye are wont to travel, on car that finds the light, laden with treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, suppliant for your help, Lovers of Sweetness! I seeking wealth call you to our libation, Hitherward let your vigorous horses bear you: drink ye with us the well-pressed Soma juices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring forward, Aśvins, Gods, to its fulfilment my never-wearied prayer that asks for riches. Vouchsafe us all high spirit in the combat, and with your powers, O Lords of Power, assist us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Favour us in these prayers of ours, O Aśvins. May we have genial vigour, ne’er to fail us. So may we, strong in children and descendants, go, wealthy, to the banquet that awaits you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lovers of Sweetness, we have brought this treasure to you as ’twere an envoy sent for friendship. Come unto us with spirits free from anger, in homes of men enjoying our oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With one, the same, intention, ye swift movers, o’er the Seven Rivers hath your chariot travelled. Yoked by the Gods, your strong steeds never weary while speeding forward at the pole they bear you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Exhaustless be your bounty to our princes who with their wealth incite the gift of riches, Who further friendship with their noble natures, combining wealth in kine with wealth in herses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now hear, O Youthful Twain, mine invocation: come, Aśvins, to the home where food aboundeth. Vouchsafe us wealth, do honour to our nobles. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXVIII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME, radiant Aśvins, with your noble horses: accept your servant's hymns, ye Wonder-Workers: Enjoy oblations which we bring to greet you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The gladdening juices stand prepared before you: come quickly and partake of mine oblation. Pass by the calling of our foe and bear us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your chariot with a hundred aids, O Aśvins, beareth you swift as thought across the regions, Speeding to us, O ye whose wealth is Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time this stone of yours, the Gods’ adorer, upraised, sounds forth for you as Soma-presser, Let the priest bring you, Fair Ones, through oblations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The nourishment ye have is, truly, wondrous: ye gave thereof a quickening store to Atri, Who being dear to you, receives your favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That gift, which all may gain, ye gave Cyavāna, when he grew old, who offered you oblations, When ye bestowed on him enduring beauty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time his wicked friends abandoned Bhujyu, O Aśvins, in the middle of the ocean, Your horse delivered him, your faithful servant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye lent your aid to Vrka when exhausted, and listened when invoked to Śayu's calling. Ye made the cow pour forth her milk like water, and, Aśvins, strengthened with your strength the barren.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With his fair hymns this singer, too, extols you, waking with glad thoughts at the break of morning. May the cow nourish him with milk to feed llim. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXIX. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY your gold chariot, drawn by vigorous horses, come to us, blocking up the earth and heaven, Bright with its fellies while its way drops fatness, food-laden, rich in coursers, man's protector.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let it approach, yoked by thewill, three-seated, extending far and wide o’er fivefold beings, Whereon ye visit God-adoring races, bending your course whither ye will, O Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Renowned, with noble horses, come ye hither: drink, Wondrous Pair, the cup that holds sweet juices. Your car whereon your Spouse is wont to travel marks with its track the farthest ends of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When night was turning to the grey of morning the Maiden, Sūrya's Daughter, chose your splendour. When with your power and might ye aid the pious he comes through heat to life by your assistance.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Chariot-borne, this car of yours invested with rays of light comes harnessed to our dwelling. Herewith, O Aśvins, while the dawn is breaking, to this our sacrifice bring peace and blessing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like the wild cattle thirsty for the lightning, Heroes, come nigh this day to our libations. Men call on you with hymns in many places, but let not other worshippers detain you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bhujyu, abandoned in the midst of ocean, ye raised from out the water with your horses, Uninjured, winged, flagging not, undaunted, with deeds of wonder saving him, O Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now hear, O Youthful Twain, mine invocation: come, Aśvins, to the home where food aboundeth. Vouchsafe us wealth, do honour to our nobles. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXX. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: RICH in all blessings, Aśvins come ye hither: this place on earth is called your own possession, Like a strong horse with a fair back it standeth, whereon, as in a lap, ye seat you firmly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This most delightful eulogy awaits you in the man's house drink-offering hath been heated, Which bringeth you over the seas and rivers, yoking as’twere two well-matched shining horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever dwellings ye possess, O Aśvins, in fields of men or in the streams of heaven, Resting upon the summit of the mountain, or bringing food to him who gives oblation,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Delight yourselves, ye Gods, in plants and waters when Ṛṣis give them and ye find they suit You. Enriching us with treasures in abundance ye have looked back to former generations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, though ye have heard them oft aforetime, regard the many prayers which Ṛṣis offer. Come to the man even as his heart desireth: may we enjoy your most delightful favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to the sacrifice offered you, Nāsatyas, with men, oblations, and prayer duly uttered. Come to Vasiṣṭha as his heart desireth, for unto you these holy hymns are chanted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is the thought, this is the song, O Aśvins: accept this hymn of ours, ye Steers, with favour. May these our prayers addressed to you come nigh you. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXI. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Night retireth from the Dawn her Sister; the Dark one yieldeth to the Red her pathway. Let us invoke you rich in steeds and cattle - by day and night keep far from us the arrow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bearing rich treasure in your car, O Aśvins, come to the mortal who presents oblation. Keep at a distance penury and sickness; Lovers of Sweetness, day and night preserve us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May your strong horses, seeking bliss, bring hither your chariot at the earliest flush of morning. With coursers yoked by Law drive hither, Aśvins, your car whose reins are light, laden with treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The chariot, Princes, that conveys you, moving at daylight, triple-seated, fraught with riches, Even with this come unto us, Nāsatyas, that laden with all food it may approach us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye freed Cyavāna from old age and weakness: ye brought the courser fleet of food to Pedu. Ye rescued Atri from distress and darkness, and loosed for Jāhuṣa the bonds that bound him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is the thought, this is the song, O Aśvins: accept this hymn of ours, ye Steers, With favour. May these our prayers addressed to you come nigh you. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME, O Nāsatyas, on your car resplendent, rich in abundant wealth of kine and horses. As harnessed steeds, all our laudations follow you whose forms shine with most delightful beauty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come with the Gods associate, come ye hither to us, Nāsatyas, with your car accordant. 'Twixt you and us there is ancestral friendship and common kin: remember and regard it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Awakened are the songs that praise the Aśvins, the kindred prayers and the Celestial Mornings. Inviting those we long for, Earth and Heaven, the singer calleth these Nāsatyas hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Dawns break forth in light, O Aśvins, to you the poets offer their devotions. God Savitar hath sent aloft his splendour, and fires sing praises with the kindled fuel.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come from the west, come from the cast, Nāsatyas, come, Aśvins, from below and from above us. Bring wealth from all sides for the Fivefold People. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXIII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE have o’erpassed the limit of this darkness while, worshipping the Gods, we sang their praises. The song invoketh both Immortal Aśvins far-reaching, born of old, great WonderWorkers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, O Nāsatyas, man's dear Priest is seated, who brings to sacrifice and offers worship, Be near and taste the pleasant juice, O Aśvins: with food, I call you to the sacrifices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We choosing you, have let our worship follow its course: ye Steers, accept this hymn with favour. Obeying you as your appointed servant, Vasiṣṭha singing hath with lauds aroused you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And these Two Priests come nigh unto our people, united, demon-slayers, mighty-handed. The juices that exhilarate are mingled. Injure us not, but come with happy fortune.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come from the west, come from the cast, Nāsatyas, come, Aśvins, from below and from above us. Bring wealth from all sides for the Fivefold People. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN I.XXIV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THESE morning sacrifices call you, Aśvins, at the break of day. For help have I invoked you rich in power and might: for, house by house ye visit all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Heroes, ye bestow wonderful nourishment. send it to him whose songs are sweet Accordant, both of you, drive your car down to us, and drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Approach ye and be near to us. drink, O ye Aśvins, of the meath. Draw forth the milk, ye Mighty, rich in genuine wealth: injure us not, and come to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The horses that convey you in their rapid flight down to the worshipper's abode, With these your speedy coursers, Heroes, Aśvins, come, ye Gods, come well-inclined to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, verily, our princes seek the Aśvins in pursuit of food. These shall give lasting glory to our liberal lords, and, both Nāsatyas, shelter us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those who have led the way, like cars, offending none, those who are guardians of the men- Also through their own might the heroes have grown strong, and dwell in safe and happy homes. Next: HYMN LXXV. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BORN in the heavens the Dawn hath flushed, and showing her majesty is come as Law ordaineth. She hath uncovered fiends and hateful darkness; best of Aṅgirases, hath waked the pathways.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rouse us this day to high and happy fortune: to great felicity, O Dawn, promote us. Vouchsafe us manifold and splendid riches, famed among mortals, man-befriending Goddess!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: See, lovely Morning's everlasting splendours, bright with their varied colours, have approached us. Filling the region of mid-air, producing the rites of holy worship, they have mounted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She yokes her chariot far away, and swiftly visits the lands where the Five Tribes are settled, Looking upon the works and ways of mortals, Daughter of Heaven, the world's Imperial Lady.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She who is rich in spoil, the Spouse of Sūrya, wondrously opulent, rules all wealth and treasures. Consumer of our youth, the seers extol her: lauded by priests rich Dawn shines out refulgent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Apparent are the steeds of varied colour, the red steeds carrying resplendent Morning. On her all-lovely car she comes, the Fair One, and brings rich treasure for her faithful servant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: True with the True and Mighty with the Mighty, with Gods a Goddess, Holy with the Holy, She brake strong fences down and gave the cattle: the kine were lowing as they greeted Morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Dawn, now give us wealth in kine and heroes, and horses, fraught with manifold enjoyment. Protect our sacred grass from man's reproaches. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXVI. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SAVITAR God of all men hath sent upward his light, designed for all mankind, immortal. Through the Gods’ power that Eye was first created. Dawn hath made all the universe apparent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I see the paths which Gods are wont to travel, innocuous paths made ready by the Vasus. Eastward the flag of Dawn hath been uplifted; she hath come hither o’er the tops of houses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great is, in truth, the number of the Mornings which were aforetime at the Sun's uprising. Since thou, O Dawn, hast been beheld repairing as to thy love, as one no more to leave him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They were the Gods’ companions at the banquet, the ancient sages true to Law Eternal. The Fathers found the light that lay in darkness, and with effectual words begat the Morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Meeting together in the same enclosure, they strive not, ofone mind, one with another. They never break the Gods’ eternal statutes, and injure none, in rivalry with Vasus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Extolling thee, Blest Goddess, the Vasisthas, awake at early mom, with lauds implore thee. Leader of kine and Queen of all that strengthens, shine, come as first to us, O high-born Morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She bringeth bounty and sweet charm of voices. The flushing Dawn is sung by the Vasisthas, Giving us riches famed to distant places. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXVIT. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SHE hath shone brightly like a youthful woman, stirring to motion every living creature. Agni hath come to feed on mortal? fuel. She hath made light and chased away the darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Turned to this All, far-spreading, she hath risen and shone in brightness with white robes about her. She hath beamed forth lovely with golden colours, Mother of kine, Guide of the days she bringeth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bearing the Gods’ own Eye, auspicious Lady, leading her Courser white and fair to look on, Distinguished by her bean-is Dawn shines apparent, come forth to all the world with wondrous treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Draw nigh with wealth and dawn away the foeman: prepare for us wide pasture free from danger. Drive away those who hate us, bring us riches: pour bounty, opulent Lady, on the singer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send thy most excellent beams to shine and light us, giving us lengthened days, O Dawn, O Goddess, Granting us food, thou who hast all things precious, and bounty rich in chariots, kine, and horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Uṣas, nobly-born, Daughter of Heaven, whom the Vasisthas with their hymns make mighty, Bestow thou on us vast and glorious riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXVIII. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE have beheld her earliest lights approaching: her many glories part, on high, asunder. On car sublime, refulgent, wending hither, O Uṣas, bring the Wealth that makes us happy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The fire well-kindIed sings aloud to greet her, and with their hymns the priests are chaming welcome. Uṣas approaches in her splendour, driving all evil darkness far away, the Goddess.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Apparent eastward are those lights of Morning, sending out lustre, as they rise, around them. She hath brought forth Sun, sacrifice, and Agni, and far away hath fled detested darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich Daughter of the Sky, we all behold her, yea, all men look on Dawn as she is breaking. fler car that moves self-harnessed hath she mounted, the car drawn onward by her well-yoked horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Inspired with loving thoughts this day to greet thee, we and our wealthy nobles have awakened. Show yourselves fruitful, Dawns, as ye are rising. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXIX. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ROUSING the lands where men's Five Tribes are settled, Dawn hath disclosed the pathways of the people. She hath sent out her sheen with beauteous oxen. The Sun with light hath opened earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They paint their bright rays on the sky's far limits. the Dawns come on like tribes arrayed for battle. Thy cattle, closely shutting up the darkness, as Savitar spreads his arms, give forth their lustre.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wealthy, most like to Indra, Dawn hath risen, and brought forth lauds that shall promote our welfare. Daughter of Heaven, a Goddess, she distributes, best of Aṅgirases, treasures to the pious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bestow on us, O Dawn, that ample bounty which thou didst send to those who sang thy praises; Thou whom with bellowings of a bull they quickened: thou didst unbar the firm-set mountain's portals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Impelling every God to grant his bounty sending to us the charm of pleasant voices, Vouchsafe us thoughts, for profit, as thou breakest. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXX. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE priests, Vasisthas, are the first awakened to welcome Uṣas with their songs and praises, Who makes surrounding regions part asunder,and shows apparent all existing creatures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Giving fresh life when she hath hid the darkness, this Dawn hath wakened there with new-born lustre. Youthful and unrestrained she cometh forward: she hath turned thoughts to Sun and fire and worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May blessed Mornings shine on us for ever, with wealth of kine, of horses, and of heroes, Streaming with all abundance, pouring fatness. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXXI. Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ADVANCING, sending forth her rays, the Daughter of the Sky is seen. Uncovering, that we may see, the mighty gloom, the friendly Lady makes the light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Sun ascending, the refulgent Star, pours down his beams together with the Dawn. O Dawn, at thine arising, and the Sun's, may we attain the share allotted us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Promptly we woke to welcome thee, O Uṣas, Daughter of the Sky, Thee, Bounteous One, who bringest all we long to have, and to the offerer health and wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, dawning, workest fain to light the great world, yea, heaven, Goddess! that it may be seen. We yearn to be thine own, Dealer of Wealth: may we be to this Mother like her sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring us that wondrous bounty, Dawn, that shall be famed most far away. What, Child of Heaven, thou hast of nourishment for man, bestow thou on us to enjoy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give to our princes opulence and immortal fame, and strength in herds of kine to us. May she who prompts the wealthy, Lady of sweet strains, may Uṣas dawn our foes away. Next: HYMN LXXXIT. Indra-Varuṇa

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GRANT us your strong protection, IndraVaruṇa, our people, and our family, for sacrifice. May we subdue in fight our evil-hearted foes, him who attacks the man steadfast in lengthened rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, mighty and very rich One of you is called Monarch and One Autocrat. All Gods in the most lofty region of the air have, O ye Steers, combined all power and might in you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye with your strength have pierced the fountains of the floods: the Sun have ye brought forward as the Lord in heaven. Cheered by this magic draught ye, Indra-Varuṇa, made the dry places stream, made songs of praise flow forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In battels and in frays we ministering priests, kneeling upon our knees for furtherance of our weal, Invoke you, only you, the Lords of twofold wealth, you prompt to hear, we bards, O Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, as ye created all these creatures of the world by your surpassing might, In peace and quiet Mitra waits on Varuṇa, the Other, awful, with the Maruis seeks renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Varuṇa's high worth may shine preeminent, these Twain have measured each his proper power and might. The One subdueth the destructive enemy; the Other with a few furthereth many a man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No trouble, no misfortune, Indra-Varuṇa, no woe from any side assails the mortal man Whose sacrifice, O Gods, ye visit and enjoy: ne’er doth the crafty guile of mortal injure him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With your divine protection, Heroes, come to us: mine invncation hear, if ye be pleased therewith. Bestow ye upon us, O Indra-Varuṇa, your friendship and your kinship and your favouring grace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In battle after battle, Indra-Varuṇa, be ye our Champions, ye who are the peoples' strength, When both opposing bands invoke you for the fight, and men that they may gain offspring and progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra, Varuṇa, Mitra, and Aryaman vouchsafe us glory and great shelter spreading far. We think of the beneficent light of Aditi, and Savitar's song of praise, the God who strengthens Law. Next: HYMN LXXXIII. Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LOOKING to you and your alliance, O ye Men, armed with broad axes they went forward, fain for spoil. Ye smote and slew his Dāsa and his Āryan enemies, and helped Sudās with favour, Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where heroes come together with their banners raised, in the encounter where is naught for us to love, Where all things that behold the light are terrified, there did ye comfort us, O Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The boundaries of earth were seen all dark with dust: O Indra-Varuṇa, the shout went up to heaven. The enmities of the people compassed me about. Ye heard my calling and ye came to me with help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With your resistless weapons, Indra-Varuṇa, ye conquered Bheda and ye gave Sudās your aid. Ye heard the prayers of these amid the cries of war: effectual was the service of the Trtsus' priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, the wickedness of foes and mine assailants' hatred sorely trouble me. Ye Twain are Lords of riches both of earth and heaven: so grant to us your aid on the decisive day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men of both the hosts invoked you in the fight, Indra and Varuṇa, that they might win the wealth, What time ye helped Sudās, with all the Trtsu folk, when the Ten Kings had pressed him down in their attack.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ten Kings who worshipped not, O Indra-Varuṇa, confederate, in war prevailed not o’er Sudās. True was the boast of heroes sitting at the feast: so at their invocations Gods were on their side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, ye gave Sudās your aid when the Ten Kings in battle compassed him about, There where the white-robed Trtsus with their braided hair, skilled in song worshipped you with homage and with hymn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One of you Twain destroys the Vṛtras in the fight, the Other evermore maintains his holy Laws. We call on you, ye Mighty, with our hymns of praise. Vouchsafe us your protection, Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra, Varuṇa, Mitra, and Aryaman vouchsafe us glory and great shelter spreading far. We think of the beneficent light of Aditi, and Savitar's song of praise, the God who strengthens Law. Next: HYMN LXXXIV. Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: KINGS, Indra-Varuṇa, I would turn you hither to this our sacrifice with gifts and homage. Held in both arms the ladle, dropping fatness, goes of itself to you whose forms are varied.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dyaus quickens and promotes your high dominion who bind with bonds not wrought of rope or cordage. Far from us still be Varuṇa's displeasure may Indra give us spacious room to dwell in.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make ye our sacrifice fair amid the assemblies: make ye our prayers approved among our princes. May God-sent riches come for our possession: further ye us with your delightful succours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, vouchsafe us riches with store of treasure, food, and every blessing; For the Āditya, banisher of falsehood, the Hero, dealeth wealth in boundless plenty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this my song reach Varuṇa and Indra, and, strongly urging, win me sons and offspring. To the Gods’ banquet may we go with riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXXV. Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR you I deck a harmless hymn, presenting the Soma juice to Varuṇa and Indra- A hymn that shines like heavenly Dawn with fatness. May they be near us on the march and guard us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here where the arrows fall amid the banners both hosts invoke the Gods in emulation. O Indra-Varuṇa, smite back those-our foemen,yea, smite them withyour shaft to every quarter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Self-lucid in their seats, e’en heavenly Waters endowed with Godhead Varuṇa and Indra. One of these holds the folk distinct and sundered, the Other smites and slays resistless foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise be the priest and skilled in Law Eternal, who with his sacred gifts and oration. Brings you to aid us with your might, Ādityas: let him have viands to promote his welfare.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this my song reach Varuṇa and Indra, and, strongly urging, win me sons and offspring. To the Gods’ banquet may we go with riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXXVI. Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WISE, verily, are creatures through his greatness who stayed ever, spacious heaven and earth asunder; Who urged the high and mighty sky to motion, the Star of old, and spread the earth before him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With mine own heart I commune on the question how Varuṇa and I may be united. What gift of mine will he accept unangered? When may I calmly look and find him gracious?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fain to know this is my sin I question others: I seek the wise, O Varuṇa, and ask them. This one same answer even the sages gave me, "Surely this Varuṇa is angry with thee."

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What, Varuṇa, hath been my chief transgression, that thou wouldst slay the friend who sings thy praises? Tell me, Unconquerable Lord, and quickly sinless will I approach thee with mine homage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Free us from sins committed by our fathers, from those wherein we have ourselves offended. O King, loose, like a thief who feeds the cattle, as from the cord a calf, set free Vasiṣṭha.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not our own will betrayed us, but seduction, thoughtlessness, Varuṇa wine, dice, or anger. The old is near to lead astray the younger: even sleep removeth not all evil-doing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slavelike may I do service to the Bounteous, serve, free from sin, the God inclined to anger. This gentle Lord gives wisdom to the simple: the wiser God leads on the wise to riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Lord, O Varuṇa, may this laudation come close to thee and lie within thy spirit. May it be well with us in rest and labour. Preserve us ever-more, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXXVII. Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: VARUNA cut a pathway out for Sūrya, and led the watery floods of rivers onward. The Mares, as in a race, speed on in order. He made great channels for the days to follow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The wind, thy breath, hath sounded through the region like a wild beast that seeks his food in pastures. Within these two, exalted Earth and Heaven, O Varuṇa, are all the forms thou lovest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa's spies, sent forth upon their errand, survey the two world-halves well formed and fashioned. Wise are they, holy, skilled in sacrifices, the furtherers of the praise-songs of the prudent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To me who understand hath Varuṇa spoken, the names borne by the Cow are three times seven. The sapient God, knowing the place's secret, shall speak as ’twere to teach the race that cometh.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On him three heavens rest and are supported, and the three earths are there in sixfold order. The wise King Varuṇa hath made in heaven that Golden Swing to cover it with glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Varuṇa from heaven he sinks in Sindhu, like a white-shining spark, a strong wild creature. Ruling in depths and meting out the region, great saving power hath he, this world's Controller.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before this Varuṇa may we be sinless him who shows mercy even to the sinner- While we are keeping Aditi's ordinances. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXXVIII. Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRESENT to Varuṇa thine hymn, Vasiṣṭha, bright, most delightful to the Bounteous Giver, Who bringeth on to us the Bull, the lofty, the Holy, laden with a thousand treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And now, as I am come before his presence, I take the face of Varuṇa for Agni's. So might he bring-Lord also of the darkness-the light in heaven that I may see its beauty!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Varuṇa and I embark together and urge our boat into the midst of ocean, We, when we ride o’er ridges of the waters, will swing within that swing and there be happy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa placed Vasiṣṭha in the vessel, and deftly with his niight made him a Ṛṣi. When days shone bright the Sage made him a singer, while the heavens broadened and the Dawns were lengthened.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What hath become of those our ancient friendships, when without enmity we walked together? I, Varuṇa, thou glorious Lord, have entered thy lofty home, thine house with thousand portals.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If he, thy true ally, hath sinned against thee, still, Varuṇa, he is the friend thou lovedst. Let us not, Living One, as sinners I know thee: give shelter, as a Sage, to him who lauds thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While we abide in these fixed habitations, and from the lap of Aditi win favour, May Varuṇa untie the bond that binds us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN LXXXIX Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET me not yet, King Varuṇa, enter into the house of clay: Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Thunderer! I move along tremulous like a wind-blown skin, Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Bright and Powerful God, through want of strength I erred and went astray Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thirst found thy worshipper though he stood in the midst of water-fijods: Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Varuṇa, whatever the offence may be which we as men commit against the heavenly host, When through our want of thought we violate thy laws, punish us not, O God, for that iniquity. Next: HYMN XC. Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
