text: To you pure juice, rich in meath, are offered by priest: through longing for the Pair of Heroes. Drive, Vāyu, bring thine harnessed horses hither: drink the pressed Soma till it make thee joyful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso to thee, the Mighty, brings oblation, pure Soma unto thee, pure-drinking Vāyu, That man thou makest famous among mortals: to him strong sons are born in quick succession.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God whom both these worlds brought forth for riches, whom heavenly Dhiṣaṇā for our wealth appointeth, His team of harnessed horses waits on Vāyu, and, foremost, on the radiant Treasure-bearer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The spotless Dawns with fair bright days have broken; they found the spacious light when they were shining. Eagerly they disclosed the stall of cattle: floods streamed for them as in the days aforetime.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These with their truthful spirit, shining brightly, move on provided with their natural insight. Viands attend the car that beareth Heroes, your car, ye Sovran Pair, Indra and Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May these who give us heavenly light, these rulers, with gifts of kine and horses, gold and treasures. These princes, through full life, Indra and Vāyu! o’ercome in battle with their steeds and heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like coursers seeking fame will we Vasisthas, O Indra-Vāyu, with our fair laudations. Exerting all our power call you to aid us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCI. Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WERE not in sooth, the Gods aforetime blameless, whose pleasure was increased by adoration? For Vāyu and for man in his affliction they caused the Morning to arise with Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guardians infallible, eager as envoys' preserve us safe through many months and autumns. Addressed to you, our fair praise, Indra-Vāyu, implores your favour and renewed well-being.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise, bright, arranger of his teams, he. seeketh men with rich food whose treasures are abundant. They have arranged them of one mind with Vāyu: the men have wrought all noble operations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So far as native power and strength permit you, so far as men behold whose eyes have vision, O ye pure-drinkers, drink with us pure Soma: sit on this sacred grass, Indra and Vāyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Driving down teams that bear the lovely Heroes, hitherward, Indra-Vāyu, come together. To you this prime of savoury juice is offered: here loose your horses and be friendly-minded.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your hundred and your thousand teams, O Indra and Vāyu, all-munificent, which attend you, With these most gracious-minded come ye hither, and drink, O Heroes of the meath we offer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like coursers seeking fame will we Vasisthas, O Indra-Vāyu, with our fair laudations, Exerting all our powe-,, call you to aid us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCII. Vāyu

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O VĀYU, drinker of the pure, be near us: a thousand teams are thine, Allbounteous Giver. To thee the rapture-bringing juice is offered, whose first draught, God, thou takest as thy portion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Prompt at the holy rites forth came the presser with Soma-draughts for Indra and for Vāyu, When ministering priests with strong devotion bring to you Twain the first taste of the Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The teams wherewith thou seekest him who offers, within his home, O Viyu, to direct him, Therewith send wealth: to us with full enjoyment, a hero son and gifts of kine and horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Near to the Gods and making Indra joyful, devout and ofFering precious gifts to Vāyu, Allied with princes, smiting down the hostile, may we with heroes conquer foes in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With thy yoked teams in hundreds and in thousands come to our sacrifice and solemn worship. Come, Vāyu, make thee glad at this libation. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCIII. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SLAYERS of enemies, Indra and Agni, accept this day our new-born pure laudation. Again, again I call you prompt to listen, best to give quickly strength to him who craves it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For ye were strong to gain, exceeding mighty, growing together, waxing in your vigour. Lords of the pasture filled with ample riches, bestow upon us strength both fresh and lasting.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea when the strong have entered our assembly, and singers seeking with their hymns your favour, They are like steeds who come into the race-course, those men who call aloud on Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The singer, seeking with his hymns your favour, begs splendid riches of their first possessor. Further us with new bounties, Indra-Agni, armed with strong thunder, slayers of the foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When two great hosts, arrayed against each other, meet clothed with brightness, in the fierce encounter Stand ye beside the godly, smite the godless; and still assist the men who press the Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To this our Soma-pressing, Indra-Agni, come ye prepared to show your loving-kindness, For not at any time have ye despised us. So may I draw you with all strengthenings hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So Agni, kindled mid this adoration, invite thou Mitra, Varuṇa, and Indra. Forgive whatever sin we have committed may Aryaman and Aditi remove it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While we accelerate these our sacrifices, may we win strength from both of you, O Agni: Ne’er may the Maruts, Indra, Viṣṇu slight us. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCIV. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As rain from out the cloud, for you, Indra and Agni, from my soul This noblest praise hath been produced.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do ye, O Indra-Agni, hear the singer's call: accept his songs. Ye Rulers, grant his heart's desire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us not up to poverty, ye Heroes, Indra-Agni, nor To slander and reproach of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra and to Agni we bring reverence, high and holy hymn, And, craving help, softwords with prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For all these holy singers here implore these Twain to succour them, And priests that they may win them strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eager to laudyou, we with songs invoke you, bearing sacred food, Fain for success in sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Agni, come to us with favour, ye who conquer men: Let not the wicked master us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At no time let the injurious blow of hostile mortal fall on us: O Indra-Agni, shelter us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever wealth we crave of you, in gold, in cattle, or in steeds, That, Indra-Agni, let us gain;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When heroes prompt in worship call Indra and Agni, Lords of steeds, Beside the Soma juice effused.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call hither with the song and lauds those who best slay the foemen, those Who take delight in hymns of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay ye the wicked man whose thought is evil of the demon kind. Slay him who stays the waters, slay the Serpent with your deadly dart. Next: HYMN XCV. Sarasvatī.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS stream Sarasvatī with fostering current comes forth, our sure defence, our fort of iron. As on a car, the flood flows on, surpassing in majesty and might all other waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pure in her course from mountains to the ocean, alone of streams Sarasvatī hath listened. Thinking of wealth and the great world of creatures, she poured for Nahuṣa her milk and fatness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Friendly to man he grew among the women, a strong young Steer amid the Holy Ladies. He gives the fleet steed to our wealthy princes, and decks their bodies for success in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this Sarasvatī be pleased and listen at this our sacrifice, auspicious Lady, When we with reverence, on our knees, implore her close-knit to wealth, most kind to those she loveth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These offerings have ye made with adoration: say this, Sarasvatī, and accept our praises; And, placing us under thy dear protection, may we approach thee, as a tree, for shelter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thee, O Blest Sarasvatī, Vasiṣṭha hath here unbarred the doors d sacred Order. Wax, Bright One, and give strength to him who lauds thee. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCVI. Sarasvatī.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I SING a lofty song, for she is mightiest, most divine of Streams. Sarasvatī will I exalt with hymns and lauds, and, O Vasiṣṭha, Heaven and Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When in the fulness of their strength the Pūrus dwell, Beauteous One, on thy two grassy banks, Favour us thou who hast the Maruts for thy friends: stir up the bounty of our chiefs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may Sarasvatī auspicious send good luck; she, rich in spoil, is never niggardly in thought, When praised in jamadagni's way and lauded as Vasiṣṭha lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call upon Sarasvān, as unmarried men who long for wives, As liberal men who yearn for sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be thou our kind protector, O Sarasvān, with those waves of thine Laden with sweets and dropping oil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we enjoy Sarasvān's breast, all-beautiful, that swells with streams, May we gain food and progeny. Next: HYMN XCVIL Bṛhaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHERE Heaven and Earth combine in men's assembly, and ttose who love the Gods delight in worship, Where the libations are effused for Indra, may he come first to drink and make him stronger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We crave the heavenly grace of Gods to guard us-so may Bṛhaspati, O friends, exalt us- That he, the Bounteous God, may find us sintess, who giveth from a distance like a father.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Brahmaṇaspati, most High and Gracious, I glorify with offerings and with homage. May the great song of praise divine, reach Indra who is the King of prayer the Gods’ creation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May that Bṛhaspati who brings all blessings, most dearly loved, be seated by our altar. Heroes and wealth we crave; may he bestow them, and bear us safe beyond the men who vex us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To us these Deathless Ones, erst born, have granted this laud of ours which gives the Immortal pleasure. Let us invoke Bṛhaspati, the foeless, the clear-voiced God, the Holy One of households

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, this Bṛhaspati, his red-hued horses, drawing together, full of strength, bring hither. Robed in red colour like the cloud, they carry the Lord of Might whose friendship gives a dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For he is pure, with hundred wings, refulgent, with sword of gold, impetuous, winning sunlight. Sublime Bṛhaspati, easy of access granteth his friends most bountiful refreshment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both Heaven and Earth, divine, the Deity's Parents, have made Bṛhaspati increase in grandeur. Glorify him, O friends, who merits glory: may he give prayer fair way and easy passage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This, Brahmaṇaspati, is your laudation prayer hath been made to thunderwielding Indra. Favour our songs, wake up our thought and spirit: destroy the godless and our foemen's malice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Twain are Lords of wealth in earth and heaven, thou, O Bṛhaspati, and thou, O Indra. Mean though he be, give wealth to him who lauds you. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRIESTS, offer to the Lord of all the people the milked-out stalk of Soma, radiant-coloured. No wild-bull knows his drinking-place like Indra who ever seeks him who hath pressed the Soma,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou dost desire to drink, each day that passes, the pleasant food which thou hast had aforetime, O Indra, gratified in heart and spirit, drink eagerly the Soma set before thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, newly-born, for strength didst drink the Soma; the Mother told thee of thy future greatness. O Indra, thou hast filled mid-air's wide region, and given the Gods by battle room and freedom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou hast urged the arrocrant to combat, proud in their strength of arm, we will subdue them. Or, Indra, when thou fightest girt by heroes, we in the glorious fray with thee will conquer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I will declare the earliest deeds of Indra, and recent acts which Maghavan hath accomplished. When he had conquered godless wiles and magic, Soma became his own entire possession.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine is this world of flocks and herds around thee, which with the eye of Sūrya thou beholdest. Thou, Indra, art alone the Lord of cattle; may we enjoy the treasure which thou givest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Twain are Lords of wealth in earth and heaven, thou, O Bṛhaspati, and thou, O Indra. Mean though he be, give wealth to him who lauds you. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN XCIX. Viṣṇu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MEN come not nigh thy majesty who growest beyond all bound and measure with thy body. Both thy two regions of the earth, O Viṣṇu, we know: thou God, knowest the highest also.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None who is born or being born, God Viṣṇu, hath reached the utmost limit of thy grandeur. The vast high vault of heaven hast thou supported, and fixed earth's eastern pinnacle securely.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich in sweet food be ye, and rich in milch-kine, with fertile pastures, fain to do men service. Both these worlds, Viṣṇu, hast thou stayed asunder, and firmly fixed the earth with pegs around it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye have made spacious room for sacrificing by generating Sūrya, Dawn, and Agni. O Heroes, ye have conquered in your battles even the bull-jawed Dāsa's wiles and magic.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye have destroyed, thou, Indra, and thou Viṣṇu, Śambara's nine-and-ninety fenced castles. Ye Twain smote down a hundred times a thousand resistless heroes of the royal Varcin.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is the lofty hymn of praise, exalting the Lords of Mighty Stride, the strong and lofty. I laud you in the solemn synods, Viṣṇu: pour ye food on us in our camps, O Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Viṣṇu, unto thee my lips cry Vaṣaṭ! Let this mine offering, Sipivista, please thee. May these my songs of eulogy exalt thee. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN C. Viṣṇu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NE’ER doth the man repent, who, seeking profit, bringeth his gift to the far-striding Viṣṇu. He who adoreth him with all his spirit winneth himself so great a benefactor.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Viṣṇu, constant in thy courses, gavest good-will to all men, and a hymn that lasteth, That thou mightst move us to abundant comfort of very splendid wealth with store of horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three times strode forth this God in all his grandeur over this earth bright with a hundred splendours. Foremost be Viṣṇu, stronger than the strongest: for glorious is his name who lives for ever.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Over this earth with mighty step strode Viṣṇu, ready to give it for a home to Manu. In him the humble people trust for safety: he, nobly born, hath made them spacious dwellings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To-day I laud this name, O gipivista, I, skilled in rules, the name of thee the Noble. Yea, I the poor and weak praise thee the Mighty who dwellest in the realm beyond this region.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What was there to be blamed in thee, O Viṣṇu, when thou declaredst, I am Sipivista? Hide not this form from us, nor keep it secret, since thou didst wear another shape in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Viṣṇu, unto thee my lips cry Vaṣaṭ! Let this mine offering, Sipivista, please thee. May these my songs of eulogy exalt thee. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN CI. Parjanya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SPEAK forth three words, the words which light precedeth, which milk this udder that produceth nectar. Quickly made manifest, the Bull hath bellowed, engendering the germ of plants, the Infant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Giver of growth to plants, the God who ruleth over the waters and all moving creatures, Vouchsafe us triple shelter for our refuge, and threefold light to succour and befriend us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now he is sterile, now begetteth offspring, even as he willeth doth he change his figure. The Father's genial flow bedews the Mother; therewith the Sire, therewith the son is nourished.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In him all living creatures have their being, and the three heavens with triply-flowing waters. Three reservoirs that sprinkle down their treasure shed their sweet streams around him with a murmur.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this my song to Sovran Lord Parjanya come near unto his heart and give him pleasure. May we obtain the showers that bring enjoyment, and God-protected plants with goodly fruitage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He is the Bull of all, and their impregner: he holds the life of all things fixed and moving. May this rite save me till my hundredth autumn. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings. Next: HYMN CII Parjanya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING forth and laud Parjanya, son of Heaven, who sends the gift of rain May he provide our pasturage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Parjanya is the God who forms in kine, in mares, in plants of earth, And womankind, the germ of life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Offer and pour into his mouth oblation rich in savoury juice: May he for ever give us food. Next: HYMN CIII. Frogs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEY who lay quiet for a year, the Brahmans who fulfil their vows, The Frogs have lifted up their voice, the voice Parjanya hath inspired.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time on these, as on a dry skin lying in the pool's bed, the floods of heaven descended, The music of the Frogs comes forth in concert like the cows lowing with their calves beside them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When at the coming of the Rains the water has poured upon them as they yearned and thirsted, One seeks another as he talks and greets him with cries of pleasure as a son his father.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Each of these twain receives the other kindly, while they are revelling in the flow of waters, When the Frog moistened by the rain springs forward, and Green and Spotty both combine their voices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When one of these repeats the other's language, as he who learns the lesson of the teacher, Your every limb seems to be growing larger as ye converse with eloquence on the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Onc is Cow-bellow and Goat-bleat the other, one Frog is Green and one of them is Spotty. They bear one common name, and yet they vary, and, talking, modulate the voice diversely.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Brahmans, sitting round the brimful vessel, talk at the Soma-rite of Atiratra, So, Frogs, ye gather round the pool to honour this day of all the year, the first of Rain-time.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Brahmans with the Soma juice, performing their year-long rite, have lifted up their voices; And these Adhvaryus, sweating with their kettles, come forth and show themselves, and none are hidden.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They keep the twelve month's God-appointed order, and never do the men neglect the season. Soon as the Rain-time in the year returneth, these who were heated kettles gain their freedom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cow-bellow and Goat-bleat have granted riches, and Green and Spotty have vouchsafed us treasure. The Frogs who give us cows in hundreds lengthen our lives in this most fertilizing season. Next: HYMN CIV. Indra-Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA and Soma, burn, destroy the demon foe, send downward, O ye Bulls, those who add gloom to gloom. Annihilate the fools, slay them and burn them up: chase them away from us, pierce the voracious ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Soma, let sin round the wicked boil like as a caldron set amid the flames of fire. Against the foe of prayer, devourer of raw flesh, the vile fiend fierce of eye, keep ye perpetual hate.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Soma, plunge the wicked in the depth, yea, cast them into darkness that hath no support, So that not one of them may ever thence return: so may your wrathful might prevail and conquer them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Soma, hurl your deadly crushing bolt down on the wicked fiend from heaven and from the earth. Yea, forge out of the mountains your celestial dart wherewith ye burn to death the waxing demon race.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Soma, cast ye downward out of heaven your deadly darts of stone burning with fiery flame, Eternal, scorching darts; plunge the voracious ones within the depth, and let them sink without a sound.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Soma, let this hymn control you both, even as the girth encompasses two vigorous steeds- The song of praise which I with wisdom offer you: do ye, as Lords of men, animate these my prayers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In your impetuous manner think ye both thereon: destroy these evil beings, slay the treacherous fiends. Indra and Soma, let the wicked have no bliss who evermore assails us with malignity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso accuses me with words of falsehood when I pursue my way with guileless spirit, May he, the speaker of untruth, be, Indra, like water which the hollowed hand compresses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those who destroy, as is their wont, the simple, and with their evil natures barm the righteous, May Soma give them over to the serpent, or to the lap of Nirrti consign them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The fiend, O Agni, who designs to injure the essence of our food, kine, steeds, or bodies, May he, the adversary, thief, and robber, sink to destruction, both himself and offipring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he be swept away, himself and children: may all the three earths press him down beneath them. May his fair glory, O ye Gods, be blighted, who in the day or night would fain destroy us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The prudent finds it easy to distinguish the true and false: their words oppose each other. Of these two that which is the true and honest, Soma protects, and brings the false to nothing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never doth Soma aid and guide the wicked or him who falsely claims the Warrior's title. He slays the fiend and him who speaks untruly: both lie entangled in the noose of Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As if I worshipped deities of falsehood, or thought vain thoughts about the Gods, O Agni. Why art thou angry with us, Jātavedas? Destruction fall on those who lie against thee!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may I die this day if I have harassed any man's life or if I be a demon. Yea, may he lose all his ten sons together who with false tongue hath called me Yātudhāna.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra slay him with a mighty weapon, and let the vilest of all creatures perish, The fiend who says that he is pure, who calls me a demon though devoid of demon nature.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She too who wanders like an owl at night-time, hiding her body in her guile and malice, May she fall downward into endless caverns. May press-stones with loud ring destroy the demons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Spread out, ye Maruts, search among the people: seize ye and grind the Rākṣasas to pieces, Who fly abroad, transformed to birds, at night-time, or sully and pollute our holy worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hurl down from heaven thy bolt of stone, O Indra: sharpen it, Maghavan, made keen by Soma. Forward, behind, and from above and under, smite down the demons with thy rocky weapon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They fly, the demon dogs, and, bent on mischief, fain would they harm indomitable Indra. Śakra makes sharp his weapon for the wicked: now, let him cast his bolt at fiendish wizards.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath ever been the fiends’ destroyer who spoil oblations of the Gods’ invokers: Yea, Śakra, like an axe that splits the timber, attacks and smashes them like earthen vessels.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Destroy the fiend shaped like an owl or owlet, destroy him in the form of dog or cuckoo. Destroy him shaped as eagle or as vulture as with a stone, O Indra, crush the demon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the fiend of witchcraft-workers reach us: may Dawn drive off the couples of Kimīdins. Earth keep us safe from earthly woe and trouble: from grief that comes from heaven mid-air preserve us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay the male demon, Indra! slay the female, joying and triumphing in arts of magic. Let the fools' gods with bent necks fall and perish, and see no more the Sun when he arises.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Look each one hither, look around Indra and Soma, watch ye well. Next: HYMN I. Indra.
